<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_do4185_1_22"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do4185_item_7._management_s_discussio__ite03599"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do4185_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item&nbsp;7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operation.    <BR>    </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Description of the Company  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc. ("Kraft"), together with its subsidiaries (collectively referred to as the "Company"), manufactures and markets packaged food products,
consisting principally of beverages, cheese, snacks, convenient meals and various packaged grocery products. Kraft manages and reports operating results through two units, Kraft North America
Commercial and Kraft International Commercial. Reportable segments for Kraft North America Commercial are organized and managed principally by product category. Kraft International Commercial's
operations are organized and managed by geographic location. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. held 98.5% of the combined voting power of Kraft's outstanding capital stock and
owned 89.0% of the outstanding shares of Kraft's capital stock. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Kraft Spin-Off from Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On January&nbsp;31, 2007, the Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. Board of Directors announced that Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. plans to spin off all of its remaining
interest (89.0%) in the Company on a pro rata basis to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. stockholders in a tax-free transaction. The distribution of all the Kraft shares owned by Altria
Group,&nbsp;Inc. will be made on March&nbsp;30, 2007 ("Distribution Date"), to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. stockholders of record as of the close of business on March&nbsp;16, 2007 ("Record
Date"). The exact distribution ratio will be calculated by dividing the number of Class A common shares of Kraft held by Altria Group, Inc. by the number of Altria Group, Inc. shares outstanding on
the Record Date. Based on the number of shares of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2006, the distribution ratio would be approximately 0.7&nbsp;shares of Kraft
Class&nbsp;A common stock for every share of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. common stock outstanding. Prior to the distribution, Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. will convert its Class&nbsp;B shares of Kraft
common stock, which carry ten votes per share, into Class&nbsp;A shares of Kraft, which carry one vote per share. Following the distribution, only Class&nbsp;A common shares of Kraft will be
outstanding and Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. will not own any shares of Kraft. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Holders
of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. stock options will be treated as public stockholders and will, accordingly, have their stock awards split into two instruments. Holders of Altria
Group,&nbsp;Inc. stock options will receive the following stock options, which, immediately after the spin-off, will have an aggregate intrinsic value equal to the intrinsic value of the
pre-spin Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. options: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>a
new Kraft option to acquire the number of shares of Kraft Class&nbsp;A common stock equal to the product of (a)&nbsp;the number of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. options
held by such person on the Distribution Date and (b)&nbsp;the approximate distribution ratio of 0.7 mentioned above; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>an
adjusted Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. option for the same number of shares of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. common stock with a reduced exercise price. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Holders
of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. restricted stock or stock rights awarded prior to January&nbsp;31, 2007, will retain their existing award and will receive restricted stock or
stock rights of Kraft Class&nbsp;A common stock. The amount of Kraft restricted stock or stock rights awarded to such holders will be calculated using the same formula set forth above with respect
to new Kraft options. All of the restricted stock and stock rights will not vest until the completion of the original restriction period (typically, three years from the date of the original grant).
Recipients of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. stock rights awarded on January&nbsp;31, 2007, did not receive restricted stock or stock rights of Kraft. Rather, they will receive additional stock rights of
Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. to preserve the intrinsic value of the original award. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To
the extent that employees of the remaining Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. receive Kraft stock options, Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. will reimburse the Company in cash for the Black-Scholes
fair value of the stock options to be received. To the extent that Kraft employees hold Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. stock options, the Company will </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>22</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=23,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=973542,FOLIO='22',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DO4185A.;10',USER='FLANGST',CD='24-FEB-2007;04:19' -->
<A NAME="page_do4185_1_23"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>reimburse
Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. in cash for the Black-Scholes fair value of the stock options. To the extent that holders of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. stock rights receive Kraft stock rights,
Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. will pay to the Company the fair value of the Kraft stock rights less the value of projected forfeitures. Based upon the number of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. stock awards
outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2006, the net amount of these reimbursements would be a payment of approximately $133&nbsp;million from the Company to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. Based upon the
number of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. stock awards outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company would have to issue 28&nbsp;million stock options and 3&nbsp;million shares of restricted
stock and stock rights. The Company estimates that the issuance of these awards would result in an approximate $0.02 decrease in diluted earnings per share. However, these estimates are subject to
change as stock awards vest (in the case of restricted stock) or are exercised (in the case of stock options) prior to the Record Date for the distribution. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
discussed in Note&nbsp;2. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, the Company is currently included in the Altria
Group,&nbsp;Inc. consolidated federal income tax return, and federal income tax contingencies are recorded as liabilities on the balance sheet of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. Prior to the distribution
of Kraft shares, Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. will reimburse the Company in cash for these liabilities, which are approximately $300&nbsp;million, plus interest. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
discussed in Note&nbsp;4. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Related Party Transactions</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, a subsidiary of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. currently provides the Company with
certain services at cost plus a 5% management fee. After the Distribution Date, the Company will undertake these activities, and any remaining limited services provided by a subsidiary of Altria
Group,&nbsp;Inc. will cease in 2007. All intercompany accounts will be settled in cash within 30 days of the Distribution Date. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Other:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In October&nbsp;2005, the Company announced that, effective January&nbsp;1, 2006, its Canadian business would be realigned to better integrate it into the
Company's North American business by product category. Beginning in the first quarter of 2006, the operating results of the Canadian business were being reported throughout the North American food
segments. Kraft North America Commercial's segments are North America Beverages; North America Cheese&nbsp;&amp; Foodservice; North America Convenient Meals; North America Grocery; and North America
Snacks&nbsp;&amp; Cereals. In addition, in the first quarter of 2006, the Company's international businesses were realigned to reflect the reorganization announced within Europe in November&nbsp;2005.
The two revised international segments are European Union; and Developing Markets, Oceania&nbsp;&amp; North Asia, the latter to reflect the
Company's increased management focus on developing markets. Accordingly, prior period segment results have been restated. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
June&nbsp;2005, the Company sold substantially all of its sugar confectionery business for pre-tax proceeds of approximately $1.4&nbsp;billion. The Company has
reflected the results of its sugar confectionery business prior to the closing date as discontinued operations on the consolidated statements of earnings. The Company recorded a loss on sale of
discontinued operations of $297&nbsp;million in the second quarter of 2005, related largely to taxes on the transaction. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's operating subsidiaries generally report year-end results as of the Saturday closest to the end of each year. This resulted in fifty-three weeks of operating
results in the Company's consolidated statement of earnings for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, versus fifty-two weeks for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2004. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>23</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=24,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=757209,FOLIO='23',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DO4185A.;10',USER='FLANGST',CD='24-FEB-2007;04:19' -->
<A NAME="page_do4185_1_24"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Executive Summary  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following executive summary is intended to provide significant highlights of the Discussion and Analysis that follows. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Consolidated Operating Results</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&#151;The changes in the Company's earnings and diluted earnings per share ("EPS") from continuing
operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 from the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, were due primarily to the following (in millions, except per share data): </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>See discussion of events affecting the comparability of statement of earnings amounts in the Consolidated Operating Results section of the following Discussion
and Analysis.</I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
unfavorable net impact of asset impairment, exit and implementation costs on earnings and diluted EPS from continuing operations is due primarily to the following: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Restructuring Program</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&#151;The Company announced a three-year restructuring program in January&nbsp;2004. In
January&nbsp;2006, the Company announced plans to expand its restructuring efforts through 2008. During the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, the Company recorded pre-tax
charges of $673&nbsp;million ($444&nbsp;million after-tax) and $297&nbsp;million ($199&nbsp;million after-tax), respectively, for the restructuring plan, including
pre-tax implementation costs of $95&nbsp;million and $87&nbsp;million, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Asset Impairment Charges</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&#151;During 2006, the Company incurred a pre-tax asset impairment charge of $86&nbsp;million
($63&nbsp;million after-tax) in recognition of the sale of its pet snacks brand and assets. In January&nbsp;2007, the Company announced the sale of its hot cereal assets and
trademarks. In recognition of the anticipated sale, the Company recorded a pre-tax asset impairment charge of $69&nbsp;million ($49&nbsp;million after-tax) in 2006 for
these assets. These charges, which included the write-off of a portion of the associated goodwill, and intangible and fixed assets, were recorded as asset impairment and exit costs on the
consolidated statement of earnings. In addition, during the first quarter of 2006, the Company completed its annual review of goodwill and intangible assets and recorded non-cash
pre-tax charges of $24&nbsp;million ($15&nbsp;million after-tax) related to an intangible asset impairment for biscuits assets in Egypt and hot cereal assets in the United
States. Also during 2006, the Company re-evaluated the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>24</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=25,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=549655,FOLIO='24',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DO4185A.;10',USER='FLANGST',CD='24-FEB-2007;04:19' -->
<A NAME="page_do4185_1_25"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>business
model for its </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Tassimo</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> hot beverage system, the revenues of which lagged the Company's projections. This evaluation resulted in a
$245&nbsp;million ($157&nbsp;million after-tax) non-cash asset impairment charge related to lower utilization of existing manufacturing capacity. These charges were
recorded as asset impairment and exit costs on the consolidated statement of earnings. In addition, the Company anticipates that the impairment will result in related cash expenditures of
approximately $3&nbsp;million, primarily related to decommissioning of idle production lines. The Company also anticipates further charges in 2007 related to negotiations with product suppliers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2005, the Company sold its fruit snacks assets and incurred a pre-tax asset impairment charge of $93&nbsp;million ($60&nbsp;million after-tax) in
recognition of the sale. During December&nbsp;2005, the Company reached agreements to sell certain assets in Canada and a
small biscuit brand in the United States and incurred pre-tax asset impairment charges of $176&nbsp;million ($80&nbsp;million after-tax) in recognition of these sales.
These transactions closed in the first quarter of 2006. These charges, which included the write-off of all associated intangible assets, were recorded as asset impairment and exit costs on
the consolidated statement of earnings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>For further details on the restructuring program or asset impairment and implementation costs, see Note&nbsp;3 to the Consolidated Financial Statements and the
Business Environment section of the following Discussion and Analysis.</I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gain on Redemption of United Biscuits Investment</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&#151;In 2006, the Company realized a pre-tax gain of
$251&nbsp;million ($148&nbsp;million after-tax) on the redemption of its outstanding investment in United Biscuits. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>For further details see Note&nbsp;6 to the
Consolidated Financial Statements</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gains on Sales of Businesses</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&#151;The 2006 gains on sales of businesses were due primarily to the sale of the Company's rice brand
and assets, partially offset by the loss on the sale of a U.S. coffee plant and tax expense of $57&nbsp;million related to the sale of the Company's pet snacks brand and assets. The 2005 gains on
sales of businesses were due primarily to the gain on sale of the Company's U.K. desserts assets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income Tax Benefit</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&#151;The 2006 tax benefit reflects a reimbursement from Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. in cash for unrequired federal
tax reserves of $337&nbsp;million and pre-tax interest of $46&nbsp;million ($29&nbsp;million after-tax), as well as net state tax reversals of $39&nbsp;million, due to
the conclusion of an audit of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s consolidated federal income tax returns for the years 1996 through 1999. Included within the change in tax rate, among other things, are a
benefit of $52&nbsp;million in 2006 and $82&nbsp;million in 2005 from the resolution of outstanding items in the Company's international operations. In addition, 2005 income taxes include
$24&nbsp;million from the settlement of an outstanding U.S. tax claim, $33&nbsp;million in tax impacts associated with the sale of a U.S. biscuit brand and a $53&nbsp;million aggregate benefit
from the domestic manufacturers' deduction provision and the dividend repatriation provision of the American Jobs Creation Act. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operations</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&#151;The $73&nbsp;million increase in results from operations, which includes the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week in 2005, was
due primarily to the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Higher
income in North America Snacks&nbsp;&amp; Cereals, reflecting higher pricing and lower marketing costs, partially offset by higher commodity costs and increased
promotional spending.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Higher
income in Developing Markets, Oceania&nbsp;&amp; North Asia, reflecting higher pricing and favorable volume/mix, partially offset by increased marketing costs, higher
product costs, and the 2005 recovery of a previously written-off account receivable.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Higher
income in North America Cheese&nbsp;&amp; Foodservice, reflecting lower commodity costs, partially offset by lower net pricing and lower volume/mix. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>25</FONT></P>

<UL>

offset by: </FONT></P>

<UL>

income in North America Beverages, reflecting higher commodity costs, partially offset by higher pricing.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Lower
income in the European Union, reflecting increased promotional spending, and higher product and marketing costs, partially offset by higher pricing. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><I>For further details, see the Consolidated Operating Results and Operating Results by Business Segment sections of the following Discussion and
Analysis.</I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Discussion and Analysis  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Note&nbsp;2 to the consolidated financial statements includes a summary of the significant accounting policies and methods used in the preparation of the
Company's consolidated financial statements. In most instances, the Company must use an accounting policy or method because it is the only policy or method permitted under accounting principles
generally accepted in the United States of America ("U.S. GAAP"). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
preparation of all financial statements includes the use of estimates and assumptions that affect a number of amounts included in the Company's financial statements, including, among
other things, employee benefit costs and income taxes. The Company bases its estimates on historical experience and other assumptions that it believes are reasonable. If actual amounts are ultimately
different from previous estimates, the revisions are included in the Company's consolidated results of operations for the period in which the actual amounts become known. Historically, the aggregate
differences, if any, between the Company's estimates and actual amounts in any year have not had a significant impact on the Company's consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
selection and disclosure of the Company's critical accounting policies and estimates have been discussed with the Company's Audit Committee. The following is a review of the more
significant assumptions and estimates, as well as the accounting policies and methods used in the preparation of the Company's consolidated financial statements: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Employee Benefit Plans.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As discussed in Note&nbsp;15 to the consolidated financial statements, the Company provides a range
of benefits to its employees and retired employees, including pensions, postretirement health care benefits and postemployment benefits (primarily severance). The Company records amounts relating to
these plans based on calculations specified by U.S. GAAP, which include various actuarial assumptions, such as discount rates, assumed rates of return on plan assets, compensation increases, turnover
rates and health care cost trend rates. The Company reviews its actuarial assumptions on an annual basis and makes modifications to the assumptions based on current rates and trends when it is deemed
appropriate to do so. As permitted by U.S. GAAP, any effect of the modifications is generally amortized over future periods. The Company believes that the assumptions utilized in recording its
obligations under its plans, which are presented in Note&nbsp;15 to the consolidated financial statements, are reasonable based on its experience and advice from its actuaries. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
September&nbsp;2006, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ("FASB") issued Statement of Financial Accounting Standards ("SFAS") No.&nbsp;158, "Employers' Accounting for Defined
Benefit Pension and Other Postretirement Plans" ("SFAS No.&nbsp;158"). SFAS No.&nbsp;158 requires that employers recognize the funded status of their defined benefit pension and other
postretirement plans on the consolidated balance sheet and record as a component of other comprehensive income, net of tax, the gains or </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>26</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=27,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=864773,FOLIO='26',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DO4185A.;10',USER='FLANGST',CD='24-FEB-2007;04:19' -->
<A NAME="page_do4185_1_27"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>losses
and prior service costs or credits that have not been recognized as components of net periodic benefit cost. The Company adopted the recognition and related disclosure provisions of SFAS
No.&nbsp;158, prospectively, on December&nbsp;31, 2006. The adoption resulted in a decrease to total assets of $2,286&nbsp;million, a decrease to total liabilities of $235&nbsp;million and a
decrease to shareholders' equity of $2,051&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SFAS
No.&nbsp;158 also requires an entity to measure plan assets and benefit obligations as of the date of its fiscal year-end statement of financial position for fiscal
years ending after December&nbsp;15, 2008. The Company's non-U.S. pension plans (other than Canadian pension plans) are measured at September&nbsp;30 of each year. The Company expects
to adopt the measurement date provision of SFAS No.&nbsp;158 and measure these plans as of December&nbsp;31 of each year beginning December&nbsp;31, 2008. The Company is presently evaluating the
impact of the measurement date change, which is not expected to be significant. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, the Company recorded the following amounts in the consolidated statements of earnings for employee benefit plans: </FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=0>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="66%"><FONT SIZE=2>Net expense for employee benefit plans</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>1,036</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>882</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="5%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>635</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=2><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
2006 net expense for employee benefit plans of $1,036&nbsp;million increased by $154&nbsp;million over the 2005 amount. This cost increase primarily relates to higher
postemployment benefit plan costs related to the restructuring program, as well as higher amortization of the unrecognized net loss from experience differences in the U.S. and non-U.S.
pension plan costs and postretirement health care costs. The 2005 net expense for employee benefit plans of $882&nbsp;million increased by $247&nbsp;million over the 2004 amount. The cost increase
primarily related to higher U.S. pension plan costs, including higher amortization of the unrecognized net loss from experience differences, a lower expected return on plan assets, a lower discount
rate assumption and higher settlement losses as employees retired or left during 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company's discount rate assumption increased from 5.60% to 5.90% for its U.S. pension and postretirement plans. The Company presently anticipates that
assumption changes, coupled with the amortization of deferred gains and losses will result in a decrease in 2007 pre-tax U.S. and non-U.S. pension and postretirement expense.
While the Company does not presently anticipate a change in its 2007 assumptions, as a sensitivity measure, a fifty-basis point decline (increase) in the Company's discount rate would increase
(decrease) the Company's U.S. pension and postretirement expense by approximately $85&nbsp;million. Similarly, a fifty-basis point decrease (increase) in the expected return on plan assets would
increase (decrease) the Company's pension expense for the U.S. pension plans by approximately $32&nbsp;million. See Note&nbsp;15 to the consolidated financial statements for a sensitivity
discussion of the assumed health care cost trend rates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenue Recognition.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As required by U.S. GAAP, the Company recognizes revenues, net of sales incentives, and including
shipping and handling charges billed to customers, upon shipment or delivery of goods when title and risk of loss pass to customers. Shipping and handling costs are classified as part of cost of
sales. Provisions and allowances for estimated sales returns and bad debts are also recorded in the Company's consolidated financial statements. The amounts recorded for these provisions and </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>27</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=28,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=729598,FOLIO='27',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DO4185A.;10',USER='FLANGST',CD='24-FEB-2007;04:19' -->
<A NAME="page_do4185_1_28"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>related
allowances are not significant to the Company's consolidated financial position or results of operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation, Amortization and Goodwill Valuation.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company depreciates property, plant and equipment and amortizes
definite life intangibles using the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company is required to conduct an annual review of goodwill and intangible assets for potential impairment. Goodwill impairment testing requires a comparison between the carrying
value and fair value of each reporting unit. If the carrying value exceeds the fair value, goodwill is considered impaired. The amount of impairment loss is measured as the difference between the
carrying value and implied fair value of goodwill, which is determined using discounted cash flows. Impairment testing for non-amortizable intangible assets requires a comparison between
the fair value and carrying value of the intangible asset. If the carrying value exceeds fair value, the intangible asset is considered impaired and is reduced to fair value. These calculations may be
affected by the market conditions noted below in the Business Environment section and under the "Risk Factors" section in Part&nbsp;1, Item&nbsp;1A of this Annual Report on
Form&nbsp;10-K, as well as interest rates, general economic conditions and projected growth rates. During the first quarter of 2006, the Company completed its annual review of goodwill
and intangible assets and recorded non-cash pre-tax charges of $24&nbsp;million related to an intangible asset impairment for biscuits assets in Egypt and hot cereal assets
in the United States. Additionally, in 2006, as part of the sale of its pet snacks brand and assets, the Company recorded non-cash pre-tax asset impairment charges of
$86&nbsp;million, which included the write-off of a portion of the associated goodwill and intangible assets of $25&nbsp;million and $55&nbsp;million, respectively, as well as
$6&nbsp;million of asset write-downs. In January&nbsp;2007, the Company announced the sale of its hot cereal assets and trademarks. In anticipation of the sale, the Company recorded a
pre-tax asset impairment charge of $69&nbsp;million in 2006 for these assets, which included the write-off of a portion of the associated goodwill and intangible assets of
$15&nbsp;million and $52&nbsp;million, respectively, as well as $2&nbsp;million of asset write-downs. During the first quarter of 2005, the Company completed its annual review of goodwill and
intangible assets and no impairment charges resulted from this review. However, as part of the sale of certain Canadian assets and two brands, the Company recorded non-cash
pre-tax asset impairment charges of $269&nbsp;million in 2005, which included impairment of goodwill and intangible assets of $13&nbsp;million and $118&nbsp;million, respectively, as
well as $138&nbsp;million of asset write-downs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Impairment of Long-Lived Assets.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company reviews long-lived assets, including amortizable
intangible assets, for impairment whenever events or changes in business circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of the assets may not be fully recoverable. The Company performs undiscounted
operating cash flow analyses to determine if an impairment exists. These analyses are affected by interest rates, general economic conditions and projected growth rates. For purposes of recognition
and measurement of an impairment of assets held for use, the Company groups assets and liabilities at the lowest level for which cash flows are separately identifiable. If an impairment is determined
to exist, any related impairment loss is calculated based on fair value. Impairment losses on assets to be disposed of, if any, are based on the estimated proceeds to be received, less costs of
disposal. As previously discussed, the Company recorded non-cash pre-tax asset impairment charges of $245&nbsp;million related to its </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Tassimo</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> hot beverage business in 2006. The charges are included in
asset impairment and exit costs in the consolidated statement of earnings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Marketing and Advertising Costs.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As required by U.S. GAAP, the Company records marketing costs as an expense in the year to
which such costs relate. The Company does not defer amounts on its year-end consolidated balance sheet with respect to marketing costs. The Company expenses advertising costs as incurred.
Consumer incentive and trade promotion activities are recorded as a reduction of revenues based on amounts estimated as being due to customers and consumers at the end of a period, based principally
on historical utilization and redemption rates. For interim reporting </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>28</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=29,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=990220,FOLIO='28',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DO4185A.;10',USER='FLANGST',CD='24-FEB-2007;04:19' -->
<A NAME="page_do4185_1_29"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>purposes,
advertising and consumer incentive expenses are charged to operations as a percentage of volume, based on estimated volume and related expense for the full year. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Related Party Transactions.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As discussed in Note&nbsp;4 to the consolidated financial statements, Altria
Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s subsidiary, Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc., provides the Company with various services, including planning, legal, treasury, auditing, insurance, human resources, office
of the secretary, corporate affairs, information technology, aviation and tax services. Billings for these services, which were based on the cost to Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. to provide
such services and a 5% management fee based on wages and benefits, were $178&nbsp;million, $237&nbsp;million and $310&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004,
respectively. These costs were paid to Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. monthly. The Company performed at a similar cost various functions in 2006 and 2005 that previously had been provided by
Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc., resulting in lower service charges in 2006 and 2005. The Company plans to undertake all remaining services currently provided by Altria Corporate
Services,&nbsp;Inc. at a similar cost in 2007. Although the cost of these services cannot be quantified on a stand-alone basis, management has assessed that the billings are reasonable based on the
level of support provided by Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc., and that they reflect all services provided. The cost and nature of the services are reviewed annually by the Company's Audit
Committee, which is comprised of independent directors. The effects of these transactions are included in operating cash flows in the Company's consolidated statements of cash flows. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2006, the Company purchased certain real estate and personal property located in Wilkes Barre, Pennsylvania, from Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc., for an aggregate purchase
price of $9.3&nbsp;million. In addition, the Company assumed all of Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc.'s rights under a lease for certain real property located in San Antonio, Texas. The Company
also purchased certain personal property located in San Antonio, Texas from Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc., for an aggregate purchase price of $6.0&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Also,
see Note&nbsp;13. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Income Taxes</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> regarding the impact to the Company of the closure of an Internal Revenue Service review of Altria
Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s consolidated federal income tax return recorded during 2006. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2005, the Company repatriated certain foreign earnings as part of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s dividend repatriation plan under provisions of the American Jobs Creation Act.
Increased taxes for this repatriation of $21&nbsp;million were reimbursed by Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. The reimbursement was reported in the Company's financial statements as an increase to
additional paid-in capital. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December&nbsp;2005, the Company purchased an airport hangar and certain personal property located at the hangar in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, from Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc.
for an aggregate purchase price of approximately $3.3&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December&nbsp;2004, the Company purchased two corporate aircraft from Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. for an aggregate purchase price of approximately $47&nbsp;million. The
Company also entered into an Aircraft Management Agreement with Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. in December&nbsp;2004, pursuant to which Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. agreed to
perform aircraft management, pilot services, maintenance and other aviation services for the Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, the Company had short-term amounts payable to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. of $607&nbsp;million and $652&nbsp;million, respectively.
The amounts payable to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. generally include accrued dividends, taxes and service fees. Interest on intercompany borrowings is based on the applicable London Interbank Offered
Rate. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income Taxes.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company accounts for income taxes in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;109, "Accounting for Income Taxes."
The U.S. accounts of the Company are included in the consolidated federal income tax return of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. Income taxes are generally computed on a separate company basis. To the extent
that foreign tax credits, capital losses and other credits generated by the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>29</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=30,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=153093,FOLIO='29',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DO4185A.;10',USER='FLANGST',CD='24-FEB-2007;04:19' -->
<A NAME="page_do4185_1_30"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Company,
which cannot currently be utilized on a separate company basis, are utilized in Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s consolidated federal income tax return, the benefit is recognized in the
calculation of the Company's provision for income taxes. Based on the Company's current estimate, this benefit is calculated to be approximately $195&nbsp;million, $225&nbsp;million and
$70&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. The amounts in 2005 and 2006 include dividend repatriations and the impact of certain legal entity
reorganizations. The benefit is dependent on a variety of tax attributes that have a tendency to vary year to year. The Company makes payments to, or is reimbursed by, Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. for
the tax effects resulting from its inclusion in Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s consolidated federal income tax return including current taxes payable and net changes in tax provisions. The Company is
assessing opportunities to mitigate the loss of tax benefits upon Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s distribution of its Kraft shares, and currently estimates the annual amount of lost tax benefits to be in
the range of $50&nbsp;million to $75&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Significant
judgment is required in determining income tax provisions and in evaluating tax positions. The Company establishes additional provisions for income taxes when, despite the
belief that existing tax positions are fully supportable, there remain certain positions that are likely to be challenged and that may not be sustained on review by tax authorities. The Company
evaluates and potentially adjusts these provisions in light of changing facts and circumstances. The consolidated tax provision includes the impact of changes to accruals that are deemed necessary.
The Company expects its effective tax rate to average 35.5% in 2007 (up from 31.7% in 2006), excluding the impact of changes for asset impairment, exit and implementation costs, and
one-time gains and losses related to acquisitions and divestitures. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2006, the United States Internal Revenue Service concluded its examination of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s consolidated tax returns for the years 1996 through 1999 and issued a final
Revenue Agents Report on March&nbsp;15, 2006. Consequently, Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. reimbursed the Company in cash for unrequired federal tax reserves of $337&nbsp;million and
pre-tax interest of $46&nbsp;million ($29&nbsp;million after-tax). The Company also recognized net state tax reversals of $39&nbsp;million, resulting in a total net
earnings benefit of $405&nbsp;million or $0.24 per diluted share during 2006. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
October&nbsp;2004, the American Jobs Creation Act ("the Jobs Act") was signed into law. The Jobs Act includes a deduction for 85% of certain foreign earnings that are repatriated.
In 2005, the Company repatriated approximately $500&nbsp;million of earnings under the provisions of the Jobs Act. Deferred taxes had previously been provided for a portion of the dividends to be
remitted. The reversal of the deferred taxes more than offset the tax costs to repatriate the earnings and resulted in a net tax reduction of $28&nbsp;million in the consolidated income tax
provision during 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
July&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;48, "Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes&#151;an interpretation of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;109"
("FIN&nbsp;48"), which will become effective for the Company on January&nbsp;1, 2007. The Interpretation prescribes a recognition threshold and a measurement attribute for the financial statement
recognition and measurement of tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return. For those benefits to be recognized, a tax position must be
more-likely-than-not to be sustained upon examination by taxing authorities. The amount recognized is measured as the largest amount of benefit that is greater than
50&nbsp;percent likely of being realized upon ultimate settlement. The adoption of FIN 48 will result in an increase to shareholders' equity as of January&nbsp;1, 2007 of approximately
$200&nbsp;million to $225&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Consolidation.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The consolidated financial statements include Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc., as well as its wholly-owned and
majority-owned subsidiaries. Investments in which Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc. exercises significant influence (20%&nbsp;- 50% ownership interest), are accounted for under the equity method of
accounting. Investments in which the Company has an ownership interest of less than 20%, or does not exercise significant influence, are accounted for by the cost method of accounting. All
intercompany transactions and balances between and among Kraft's subsidiaries have been eliminated. Transactions between any of the Company's businesses and Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. and its
affiliates are included in the consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>30</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dq4185_1_31"> </A> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Business Environment  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is subject to a number of challenges that may adversely affect its businesses. These challenges, which are discussed below and under the "Risk
Factors" section in Part&nbsp;1, Item 1A of this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K, include: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>fluctuations
in commodity prices;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>movements
of foreign currencies;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>competitive
challenges in various products and markets, including price gaps with competitor products and the increasing price-consciousness of consumers;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>a
rising cost environment and the limited ability to increase prices;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>a
trend toward increasing consolidation in the retail trade and consequent pricing pressure and inventory reductions;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>a
growing presence of discount retailers, primarily in Europe, with an emphasis on own-label products;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>changing
consumer preferences, including diet and health/wellness trends;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>competitors
with different profit objectives and less susceptibility to currency exchange rates; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>increasing
scrutiny of product labeling and marketing practices as well as concerns and/or regulations regarding food safety, quality and health, including genetically
modified organisms, trans-fatty acids and obesity. Increased government regulation of the food industry could result in increased costs to the Company. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the ordinary course of business, the Company is subject to many influences that can impact the timing of sales to customers, including the timing of holidays and other annual or
special events, seasonality of certain products, significant weather conditions, timing of Company or customer incentive programs and pricing actions, customer inventory programs, Company initiatives
to improve supply chain efficiency, financial condition of customers and general economic conditions. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fluctuations
in commodity costs can lead to retail price volatility and intense price competition, and can influence consumer and trade buying patterns. During 2006, the Company's
commodity costs on average were higher than those incurred in 2005 (most notably higher coffee, energy and packaging costs, partially offset by lower cheese and meat costs), and adversely affected
earnings. For 2006, the Company's commodity costs were approximately $275&nbsp;million higher than 2005, following an increase of approximately $800&nbsp;million for 2005 compared with 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Restructuring:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January&nbsp;2004, the Company announced a three-year restructuring program (which is discussed further in Note&nbsp;3. </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Asset Impairment, Exit and
Implementation Costs</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>) with the objectives of leveraging the Company's global scale, realigning and lowering its cost
structure, and optimizing capacity utilization. In January&nbsp;2006, the Company announced plans to expand its restructuring efforts through 2008. The entire restructuring program is expected to
result in $3.0&nbsp;billion in pre-tax charges, the closure of up to 40 facilities, the elimination of approximately 14,000 positions and annualized cost savings at the completion of the
program of approximately $1.0&nbsp;billion. The decline of $700&nbsp;million from the $3.7&nbsp;billion in pre-tax charges previously announced was due primarily to lower than
projected severance costs, the cancellation of an initiative intended to generate sales efficiencies, and the sale of one plant that was originally planned to be closed. Approximately
$1.9&nbsp;billion of the $3.0&nbsp;billion in pre-tax charges are expected to require cash payments. Total pre-tax restructuring program charges incurred, including
implementation costs, were $673&nbsp;million, $297&nbsp;million and $641&nbsp;million in 2006, 2005 and 2004, </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>31</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=32,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=318935,FOLIO='31',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DQ4185A.;30',USER='EYOUNG',CD='28-FEB-2007;08:37' -->
<A NAME="page_dq4185_1_32"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>respectively.
Total pre-tax restructuring charges for the program incurred from January&nbsp;2004 through December&nbsp;31, 2006 were $1.6&nbsp;billion and specific programs
announced will result in the elimination of approximately 9,800 positions. Approximately 60% of the pre-tax charges to date are expected to require cash payments. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, the Company expects to incur approximately $550&nbsp;million in capital expenditures to implement the restructuring program. From January&nbsp;2004 through
December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company spent $245&nbsp;million in capital, including $101&nbsp;million spent in 2006, to implement the restructuring program. Cumulative annualized cost savings as a
result of the restructuring program were approximately $540&nbsp;million and $260&nbsp;million through December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively, and are anticipated to reach approximately
$700&nbsp;million by the end of 2007, all of which are expected to be used in support of brand-building initiatives. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Asset Impairment Charges:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As discussed further in Note&nbsp;3. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Asset Impairment, Exit and Implementation Costs</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, the Company incurred
pre-tax asset impairment charges of $424&nbsp;million, $269&nbsp;million and $20&nbsp;million during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. These
charges were recorded as asset impairment and exit costs on the consolidated statements of earnings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;These
asset impairment charges primarily related to various sales of the Company's brands and assets, as well as the 2006 re-evaluation of the business model for the
Company's </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Tassimo</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> hot beverage system, the revenues of which lagged the Company's projections. This evaluation resulted in a $245&nbsp;million
non-cash pre-tax asset impairment charge related to lower utilization of existing manufacturing capacity. In addition, the Company anticipates that the impairment will result
in related cash expenditures of approximately $3&nbsp;million, primarily related to decommissioning of idle production lines. The Company also anticipates further charges in 2007 related to
negotiations with product suppliers. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Acquisitions and Dispositions:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;One element of the Company's growth strategy is to strengthen its brand portfolios and/or expand its geographic reach through a disciplined program of selective
acquisitions and divestitures. The Company is constantly reviewing potential acquisition candidates and from time to time sells businesses to accelerate the shift in its portfolio toward
businesses&#151;whether global, regional or local&#151;that offer the Company a sustainable competitive advantage. The impact of any future acquisition or divestiture could have a
material impact on the Company's consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows, and future sales of businesses could in some cases result in losses on sale. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2006, the Company acquired the Spanish and Portuguese operations of United Biscuits ("UB"), and rights to all Nabisco trademarks in the European Union, Eastern Europe, the Middle
East and Africa, which UB has held since 2000, for a total cost of approximately $1.1&nbsp;billion. The Spanish and Portuguese operations of UB include its biscuits, dry desserts, canned meats,
tomato and fruit juice businesses as well as seven manufacturing facilities and 1,300 employees. From September&nbsp;2006 to December&nbsp;31, 2006, these businesses contributed net revenues of
$111&nbsp;million. The non-cash acquisition was financed by the Company's assumption of $541&nbsp;million of debt issued by the acquired business immediately prior to the acquisition,
as well as $530&nbsp;million of value for the redemption of the Company's outstanding investment in UB, primarily deep-discount securities. The redemption of the Company's investment in
UB resulted in a pre-tax gain on closing of $251&nbsp;million ($148&nbsp;million after-tax or $0.09 per diluted share). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aside
from the debt assumed as part of the acquisition price, the Company acquired assets consisting primarily of goodwill of $734&nbsp;million, other intangible assets of
$217&nbsp;million, property, plant and equipment of $161&nbsp;million, receivables of $101&nbsp;million and inventories of $34&nbsp;million. These amounts </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>32</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=33,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=228759,FOLIO='32',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DQ4185A.;30',USER='EYOUNG',CD='28-FEB-2007;08:37' -->
<A NAME="page_dq4185_1_33"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>represent
the preliminary allocation of purchase price and are subject to revision when appraisals are finalized, which is expected to occur during the first half of 2007. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2006, the Company sold its rice brand and assets, and its industrial coconut assets. The Company also sold its pet snacks brand and assets in 2006 and recorded tax expense of
$57&nbsp;million related to the sale. In addition, the Company incurred a pre-tax asset impairment charge of $86&nbsp;million in 2006 in recognition of this sale. Additionally, during
2006, the Company sold certain Canadian assets and a small U.S. biscuit brand, and incurred pre-tax asset impairment charges of $176&nbsp;million in 2005 in recognition of these sales.
Also during 2006, the Company sold a U.S. coffee plant. The aggregate proceeds received from these sales were $946&nbsp;million, on which the Company recorded pre-tax gains of
$117&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
January&nbsp;2007, the Company announced the sale of its hot cereal assets and trademarks. In recognition of the anticipated sale, the Company recorded a pre-tax asset
impairment charge of $69&nbsp;million in 2006 for these assets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
previously discussed, the Company sold substantially all of its sugar confectionery business in June&nbsp;2005 for pre-tax proceeds of approximately $1.4&nbsp;billion.
The sale included the </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Life Savers</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Creme Savers</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Altoids</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Trolli</I></FONT><FONT
SIZE=2> and </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Sugus</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> brands. The Company has
reflected the results of its sugar confectionery business prior to the closing date as discontinued operations on the consolidated statements of earnings. The Company recorded a loss on sale of
discontinued operations of $297&nbsp;million in the second quarter of 2005, related largely to taxes on the transaction. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2005, the Company sold its fruit snacks assets, and incurred a pre-tax asset impairment charge of $93&nbsp;million in recognition of this sale. Additionally, during
2005, the Company sold its U.K. desserts assets, its U.S. yogurt assets, a small business in Colombia, a minor trademark in Mexico and a small equity investment in Turkey. The aggregate proceeds
received from these sales were $238&nbsp;million, on which the Company recorded pre-tax gains of $108&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2004, the Company sold a Brazilian snack nuts business and trademarks associated with a candy business in Norway. The aggregate proceeds received from the sales of these
businesses were $18&nbsp;million, on which pre-tax losses of $3&nbsp;million were recorded. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2004, the Company acquired a U.S.-based beverage business for a total cost of $137&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
operating results of the businesses acquired and sold, other than the UB acquisition and the divestiture of the sugar confectionery business, in the aggregate, were not material to
the Company's consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows in any of the periods presented. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>33</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>34</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=35,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=490483,FOLIO='34',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DQ4185A.;30',USER='EYOUNG',CD='28-FEB-2007;08:37' -->
<A NAME="page_dq4185_1_35"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating income was affected by the following items during 2006, 2005 and 2004: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Asset impairment, exit and implementation costs&#151;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>As discussed in Note&nbsp;3 to the consolidated financial
statements, during 2006, 2005 and 2004, the Company recorded $1,002&nbsp;million, $479&nbsp;million and $603&nbsp;million, respectively, of asset impairment and exit costs on its consolidated
statement of earnings. Additionally, during 2006, 2005 and 2004, the Company recorded pre-tax implementation costs of $95&nbsp;million, $87&nbsp;million and
$50&nbsp;million, respectively. During 2004, the Company also recorded $47&nbsp;million of pre-tax impairment charges related to its equity investment in a joint venture in Turkey. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
pre-tax asset impairment, exit and implementation costs for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, were included in the operating companies income of
the following segments: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH WIDTH="30%" ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=14 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>For the Year Ended December&nbsp;31, 2006</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Gain on Redemption of United Biscuits Investment&#151;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>As more fully discussed in Note&nbsp;6. </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Acquisitions</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, in the third
quarter of 2006, the Company acquired the Spanish and Portuguese operations of United Biscuits ("UB") and rights to all
Nabisco trademarks in the European Union, Eastern Europe, the Middle East and Africa. The redemption of the Company's outstanding investment in UB resulted in a pre-tax gain on closing of
$251&nbsp;million. This gain is included in the operating companies income of the European Union segment.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Gains/Losses on Sales of Businesses&#151;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>During 2006, the Company sold its rice brand and assets, pet snacks brand and
assets, industrial coconut assets, certain Canadian assets, a small U.S. biscuit brand and a U.S. coffee plant for aggregate pre-tax gains of $117&nbsp;million. During 2005, the Company
sold its fruit snacks assets, U.K. desserts assets, U.S. yogurt assets, a small business in Colombia, a minor trademark in Mexico and a small equity investment in Turkey for aggregate
pre-tax gains of $108&nbsp;million. During 2004, the Company sold a Brazilian snack nuts business and trademarks associated with a candy business in Norway for aggregate
pre-tax losses of $3&nbsp;million. These pre-tax (gains) losses were included in the operating companies income of the following segments: </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As discussed in Note&nbsp;14 to the consolidated financial statements, the Company's management uses operating companies income, which is defined as operating
income before general corporate expenses and amortization of intangibles, to evaluate segment performance and allocate resources. Management believes it is appropriate to disclose this measure to help
investors analyze the business performance and trends of the various business segments. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>36</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=37,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=904441,FOLIO='36',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DQ4185A.;30',USER='EYOUNG',CD='28-FEB-2007;08:37' -->
<A NAME="page_dq4185_1_37"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2006 compared with 2005  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following discussion compares consolidated operating results for 2006 with 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's 2005 results included 53 weeks of operating results compared with 52 weeks in 2006. The Company estimates that this extra week positively impacted net revenues and
operating income by approximately 2% in 2005 (approximately $625&nbsp;million and $100&nbsp;million, respectively), causing a negative comparison to 2006. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume
decreased 961&nbsp;million pounds (5.0%), including the 53rd week in 2005 results. Excluding the impact of divestitures, the acquisition of UB and the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week of
shipments in 2005, volume decreased 0.4%, due primarily to the discontinuation of certain ready-to-drink and foodservice product lines and lower grocery shipments in North
America, partially offset by higher shipments of meat, biscuits and cheese in North America and higher shipments in Developing Markets, Oceania&nbsp;&amp; North Asia. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $243&nbsp;million (0.7%), due primarily to favorable volume/mix ($244&nbsp;million, including the 53rd week in 2005), higher net pricing ($229&nbsp;million,
reflecting commodity-driven pricing, partially offset by increased promotional spending), favorable currency ($145&nbsp;million) and the acquisition of UB ($111&nbsp;million), partially offset by
the impact of divested businesses ($488&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
income decreased $226&nbsp;million (4.8%), due primarily to higher pre-tax asset impairment and exit costs ($523&nbsp;million), 2005 net gains on the sales of
businesses ($108&nbsp;million), higher marketing costs ($85&nbsp;million) and the impact of divestitures ($71&nbsp;million), partially offset by the 2006 gain on redemption of the Company's UB
investment ($251&nbsp;million), the 2006 net gains on sales of businesses ($117&nbsp;million), higher net pricing ($72&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing, partially offset by
increased promotional spending and higher costs), lower fixed manufacturing costs ($40&nbsp;million), favorable volume/mix ($32&nbsp;million, including the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week in 2005),
favorable currency ($29&nbsp;million) and the acquisition of UB ($18&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Currency
movements increased net revenues by $145&nbsp;million and operating income by $29&nbsp;million. These increases were due primarily to the weakness of the U.S. dollar against
the Canadian dollar and the Brazilian real, partially offset by the strength of the U.S. dollar against the euro. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest
and other debt expense, net decreased $126&nbsp;million (19.8%) due primarily to $46&nbsp;million of pre-tax interest income associated with the conclusion of a
tax audit at Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc., lower debt levels and the redemption of higher coupon Nabisco bonds, partially offset by higher short-term interest rates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's income tax rate decreased by 5.7&nbsp;percentage points to 23.7%. The 2006 tax rate includes a reimbursement from Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. in cash for unrequired federal
tax reserves of $337&nbsp;million, and net state tax reversals of $39&nbsp;million, due to the conclusion of an audit of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s consolidated federal income tax returns for the
years 1996 through 1999. Included within the change in tax rates, among other things, are a benefit of $52&nbsp;million in 2006 and $82&nbsp;million in 2005 from the resolution of outstanding
items in the Company's international operations. In addition, in 2005 income taxes include $24&nbsp;million from the settlement of an outstanding U.S. tax claim, $33&nbsp;million of tax impacts
associated with the sale of a U.S. biscuit brand and a $53&nbsp;million aggregate benefit from the domestic manufacturers' deduction provision and the dividend repatriation provision of the Jobs
Act. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Earnings
from continuing operations of $3,060&nbsp;million increased $156&nbsp;million (5.4%), due primarily to the tax benefit discussed above and lower interest expense, partially
offset by lower operating income (reflecting higher asset impairment and exit costs in 2006). Diluted EPS from continuing operations, which was $1.85, increased by 7.6%. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>37</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=38,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=546079,FOLIO='37',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DQ4185A.;30',USER='EYOUNG',CD='28-FEB-2007;08:37' -->
<A NAME="page_dq4185_1_38"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
loss from discontinued operations, net of income taxes, in 2005 was due primarily to the recording of additional tax expense of $297&nbsp;million that arose from the sale of the
sugar confectionery business in the second quarter of 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
earnings of $3,060&nbsp;million increased $428&nbsp;million (16.3%). Diluted EPS from net earnings, which was $1.85, increased by 19.4%. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2005 compared with 2004  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following discussion compares consolidated operating results for 2005 with 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's 2005 results included 53 weeks of operating results compared with 52 weeks in 2004. The Company estimates that this extra week positively impacted net revenues and
operating income by approximately 2% in 2005 (approximately $625&nbsp;million and $100&nbsp;million, respectively). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume
increased 210&nbsp;million pounds (1.1%), including the benefit of 53 weeks in 2005 results. Excluding all acquisitions and divestitures, and the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week of
shipments, volume decreased approximately 1% due primarily to a focus on mix improvement, a SKU reduction program, the impact of higher retail prices on category growth trends in the United States and
declines in certain international countries (most notably Germany), partially offset by new product introductions and growth in developing markets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $1,945&nbsp;million (6.0%) due primarily to favorable volume/mix ($1,086&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week), favorable
currency ($533&nbsp;million), higher net pricing ($453&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing, partially offset by increased promotional spending) and the impact of acquisitions
($42&nbsp;million), partially offset by the impact of divested businesses ($174&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
income increased $140&nbsp;million (3.0%), due primarily to favorable volume/mix ($479&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week), lower asset
impairment and exit costs ($124&nbsp;million), net gains on the sales of businesses ($111&nbsp;million), favorable currency ($90&nbsp;million) and a 2004 equity investment impairment charge
related to a joint venture in Turkey ($47&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher marketing, administration and research costs ($420&nbsp;million, including higher benefit and marketing costs,
as well as costs associated with the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week), higher fixed manufacturing costs ($110&nbsp;million), unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing ($102&nbsp;million, due primarily to
higher commodity costs and increased promotional spending), the net impact of higher implementation costs associated with the restructuring program ($37&nbsp;million), and the impact of divestitures
($33&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Currency
movements increased net revenues by $533&nbsp;million and operating income by $90&nbsp;million. These increases were due primarily to the weakness of the U.S. dollar against
the euro, the Canadian dollar, the Brazilian real and certain other currencies. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's reported effective income tax rate decreased by 2.9&nbsp;percentage points to 29.4%, due primarily to the settlement of an outstanding U.S. tax claim of
$24&nbsp;million; $82&nbsp;million from the resolution of outstanding items in the Company's international operations; and $33&nbsp;million in tax impacts associated with the sale of a U.S.
biscuit brand. The 2005 rate also includes a $53&nbsp;million aggregate benefit from the domestic manufacturers' deduction provision and the dividend repatriation provision of the American Jobs
Creation Act. The tax provision in 2004 included the $81&nbsp;million favorable resolution of an outstanding tax item and the reversal of $35&nbsp;million of tax accruals that were no longer
required due to tax events that occurred during 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Earnings
from continuing operations of $2,904&nbsp;million increased $235&nbsp;million (8.8%), due primarily to higher operating income and a lower income tax rate. Diluted EPS from
continuing operations, which was $1.72, increased by 11.0%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Loss
from discontinued operations, net of income tax, increased $268&nbsp;million, due primarily to a loss on sale of $297&nbsp;million in 2005. The loss from discontinued operations
was due primarily to the recording </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>38</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>of
additional tax expense that arose from the sale of the sugar confectionery business in the second quarter of 2005. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
earnings of $2,632&nbsp;million decreased $33&nbsp;million (1.2%). Diluted EPS from net earnings, which was $1.55, was equal to 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Operating Results by Reportable Segment  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2006 compared with 2005  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following discussion compares operating results within each of Kraft's reportable segments for 2006 with 2005. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;North America Beverages.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume decreased 6.8%, including the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week of shipments in
2005 (representing approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of decline), due primarily to a decline in refreshment beverages volume resulting from the discontinuation of certain
ready-to-drink product lines and lower shipments of coffee. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $32&nbsp;million (1.0%), due primarily to higher pricing, net of increased promotional spending ($36&nbsp;million) and favorable currency ($14&nbsp;million),
partially offset by lower volume/mix ($17&nbsp;million, including the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week in 2005). Coffee net revenues increased due to higher commodity-based pricing, partially offset by lower
shipments. In powdered beverages, favorable mix from new products also drove higher net revenues. Ready-to-drink net revenues declined due to lower shipments and
discontinuation of certain products. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $258&nbsp;million (55.7%), due primarily to the loss on the sale of a U.S. coffee plant ($95&nbsp;million), higher pre-tax charges
for asset impairment and exit costs ($85&nbsp;million, including $75&nbsp;million as part of the </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Tassimo</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> asset impairment) and unfavorable costs,
net of higher pricing ($69&nbsp;million, including higher commodity costs). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;North America Cheese&nbsp;&amp; Foodservice.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume decreased 4.8%, including the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>
week of shipments in 2005 (representing approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of decline), due primarily to the divestitures of Canadian grocery assets, U.S. yogurt assets and industrial coconut
assets, and lower volume in foodservice. In foodservice, volume declined due to the discontinuation of lower margin product lines. Cheese volume was flat as higher shipments of natural and cream
cheese were offset by the impact of divestitures and the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week of shipments in 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues decreased $166&nbsp;million (2.7%), due primarily to lower net pricing ($114&nbsp;million, representing increased promotional spending, net of higher pricing), lower
volume/mix ($60&nbsp;million,
including the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week in 2005) and the impact of divestitures ($53&nbsp;million), partially offset by favorable currency ($61&nbsp;million). In foodservice, net revenues decreased
due primarily to lower volume, the impact of divestitures and lower cheese pricing, partially offset by favorable currency. Cheese net revenues decreased due primarily to lower net pricing in response
to declining cheese costs and the impact of divestitures, partially offset by favorable currency. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $35&nbsp;million (3.8%), due primarily to higher pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($72&nbsp;million), lower
volume/mix ($22&nbsp;million, including the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week in 2005), higher marketing spending ($20&nbsp;million), higher implementation costs ($11&nbsp;million) and the 2006 loss on
sale of industrial coconut assets ($8&nbsp;million), partially offset by favorable costs (primarily cheese commodity costs), net of lower net pricing ($79&nbsp;million), lower fixed manufacturing
costs ($11&nbsp;million) and favorable currency ($9&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;North America Convenient Meals.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 0.5%, despite the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week of
shipments in 2005 (representing approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of decline), driven by higher meat shipments (cold cuts, hot dogs and bacon) and higher shipments of pizza, partially offset by
lower shipments of dinners, due to competition in macaroni and cheese dinners, and the divestiture of the rice brand and assets. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>39</FONT></P>
