<P><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net revenues increased $144&nbsp;million (3.1%), due primarily to higher volume/mix ($138&nbsp;million, including the 53<SUP>rd</SUP> week in 2005), favorable currency
($14&nbsp;million) and higher pricing, net of increased promotional spending ($7&nbsp;million), partially offset by the impact of divestitures ($15&nbsp;million). In meats, higher net revenues
were driven by continued strong results for new products and higher net pricing. Pizza net revenues increased due to higher shipments and favorable mix from new products, partially offset by higher
promotional spending. Dinners net revenues decreased due to the impact of lower volume. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income increased $121&nbsp;million (15.3%), due primarily to the 2006 gain on the sale of the rice brand and assets ($226&nbsp;million), lower fixed manufacturing
costs ($24&nbsp;million) and favorable currency ($4&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($93&nbsp;million), higher product
costs and promotional spending, net of higher pricing ($24&nbsp;million), the impact of divestitures ($9&nbsp;million) and higher implementation costs ($5&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;North America Grocery.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume decreased 21.6%, including the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week of
shipments in 2005 (representing approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of decline), due primarily to the divestitures of fruit snacks and Canadian grocery assets, the discontinuation of certain
Canadian condiment product lines and lower shipments of ready-to-eat and dry packaged desserts, and spoonable salad dressings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues decreased $293&nbsp;million (9.7%), due primarily to the impact of divestitures ($266&nbsp;million) and lower volume/mix ($85&nbsp;million, including the
53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week in 2005), partially offset by higher pricing ($30&nbsp;million) and the impact of favorable currency ($26&nbsp;million). Ready-to-eat and dry
packaged desserts net revenues declined due to lower shipment volume. In spoonable salad dressing, net revenues decreased due to lower shipments, partially offset by lower promotional spending.
Pourable salad dressing net revenues declined due to higher promotional spending. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income increased $195&nbsp;million (26.9%), due primarily to lower pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($206&nbsp;million, including
the $113&nbsp;million asset impairment charge in 2005 related to the sale of the Canadian grocery assets and the $93&nbsp;million asset impairment charge related to the 2005 sale of the fruit
snacks assets), lower marketing, administration and research costs ($30&nbsp;million, including costs associated with the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week in 2005), favorable currency
($8&nbsp;million) and higher pricing, net of unfavorable costs ($7&nbsp;million), partially offset by lower volume/mix ($50&nbsp;million, including the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week in 2005)
and the impact of divestitures ($9&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;North America Snacks&nbsp;&amp; Cereals.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume decreased 3.4%, including the
53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week of shipments in 2005 (representing approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of decline), due primarily to the divestitures of the pet snacks brand and assets, and a
small biscuit brand, and lower shipments of snack nuts, partially offset by higher shipments of biscuits and snack bars. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $108&nbsp;million (1.7%), due primarily to favorable volume/mix ($106&nbsp;million, including the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week in 2005) and higher pricing,
net of increased promotional spending ($86&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing in biscuits and ready-to-eat cereals) and favorable currency
($38&nbsp;million), partially offset by the impact of divestitures ($123&nbsp;million). Biscuit net revenues increased due to higher pricing to offset the impact of commodity cost increases in
energy and packaging, higher shipment volume and favorable mix. In snack bars, net revenue increases were driven by new product introductions. Canadian snack net revenues also increased due to sales
of co-manufactured products related to the 2005 divested confectionery business. Snack nuts net revenues decreased due to lower shipments. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $101&nbsp;million (10.9%), due primarily to higher pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($138&nbsp;million, including
the $86&nbsp;million asset impairment charge in 2006 related to the sale of the pet snacks brand and assets, the $69&nbsp;million impairment charge in 2006 related to the sale of the hot cereal
assets and trademarks, the $13&nbsp;million hot cereal intangible asset impairment in 2006 and the $63&nbsp;million asset impairment charge in 2005 related to the sale of a small biscuit brand),
the impact of divestitures ($47&nbsp;million) and 2006 losses on sales of businesses </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>40</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>($5&nbsp;million),
partially offset by lower marketing spending ($48&nbsp;million), lower fixed manufacturing costs ($10&nbsp;million), lower implementation costs ($10&nbsp;million), higher

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;European Union.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 2.0%, despite the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week of shipments in
2005 (representing approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of decline), due primarily to the acquisition of UB, partially offset by lower shipments across several sectors and the divestiture of the
U.K. desserts assets in the first quarter of 2005. Snacks volume increased due primarily to the acquisition of UB and higher confectionery shipments, particularly in Poland. Convenient meals volume
was up due primarily to the acquisition of UB, partially offset by lower shipments in Germany and the Nordic area. Grocery volume declined due primarily to the divestiture of the U.K. desserts assets
and lower shipments in Germany, partially offset by the acquisition of UB. In beverages, coffee volume declined across most countries except Germany and refreshment beverages shipments were lower. In
cheese&nbsp;&amp; dairy, volume decreased due to lower shipments in Germany and Italy. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues decreased $42&nbsp;million (0.6%), due primarily to unfavorable currency ($93&nbsp;million), unfavorable volume/mix ($53&nbsp;million, including the
53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week in 2005) and the impact of divestitures
($12&nbsp;million), partially offset by the acquisition of UB ($110&nbsp;million) and higher pricing, net of increased promotional spending ($6&nbsp;million). In cheese&nbsp;&amp; dairy, net
revenues decreased due to lower shipments, unfavorable currency and lower net pricing. Grocery net revenues declined due to unfavorable currency and the impact of the divestiture of the U.K. desserts
business, partially offset by the acquisition of UB. In beverages, net revenues declined due to unfavorable currency and lower coffee and refreshment beverage shipments, partially offset by
commodity-related pricing and favorable mix in coffee. Convenient meals net revenues also decreased, due to unfavorable currency and lower shipments, partially offset by the impact of the acquisition
of UB. Snacks net revenues increased due primarily to the acquisition of UB for biscuits and higher shipments and pricing in confectionery, partially offset by unfavorable currency. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $174&nbsp;million (24.1%), due primarily to higher pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($273&nbsp;million, including
$170&nbsp;million of asset impairment charges related to </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Tassimo</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>), the gain on the sale of U.K. desserts assets in 2005 ($115&nbsp;million),
unfavorable costs and increased promotional spending, net of higher pricing ($31&nbsp;million), higher marketing, administration and research costs ($17&nbsp;million, including costs associated
with the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week in 2005) and unfavorable currency ($14&nbsp;million), partially offset by the 2006 gain on the redemption of the Company's outstanding investment in UB
($251&nbsp;million), the impact of the acquisition of UB ($18&nbsp;million) and lower fixed manufacturing costs ($14&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Developing Markets, Oceania&nbsp;&amp; North Asia.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume decreased 0.9%, including the
53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week of shipments in 2005 (representing approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of decline), as lower volume in Asia Pacific was partially offset by growth in Eastern Europe
and Latin America. In cheese and dairy, volume declined in Asia Pacific, partially offset by higher shipments in the Middle East. Grocery volume declined due to lower shipments in Brazil, Mexico,
Venezuela and the Middle East. In beverages, volume declined due to the discontinuation of a product line in Mexico and lower shipments in Southeast Asia and the Middle East, partially offset by
higher coffee volume in Russia, Ukraine and Romania, and higher refreshment beverage volume in China. Snacks volume increased driven by higher shipments in Brazil reflecting confectionery growth and
gains in biscuits, and growth in Venezuela, Russia, Southeast Asia, Romania and Ukraine. Convenient meals volume decreased slightly. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $460&nbsp;million (11.2%), due primarily to favorable volume/mix ($215&nbsp;million, including the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week in 2005), higher pricing
($178&nbsp;million) and favorable currency ($85&nbsp;million), partially offset by the impact of divestitures ($19&nbsp;million). In snacks, net revenues grew due to higher volume as well as
favorable pricing in Latin America and favorable currency in Brazil. Confectionery net revenues also increased, due to growth in Russia and Ukraine. Coffee net revenues increased due to </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>41</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>commodity-based
pricing, favorable mix and higher shipments in Russia, Ukraine and Romania. In refreshment beverages, higher shipments in Brazil and favorable pricing in Mexico drove higher net
revenues. Cheese&nbsp;&amp; dairy net revenue increases were driven by higher shipments in the Middle East. In convenient meals, net revenues were up slightly. Grocery net revenues declined due to the
impact of a divestiture in Colombia. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income increased $16&nbsp;million (4.0%), due primarily to higher pricing, net of unfavorable costs ($102&nbsp;million), favorable volume/mix ($93&nbsp;million,
including the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week in 2005), favorable currency ($16&nbsp;million), the losses on sales of businesses in 2005 ($5&nbsp;million) and lower implementation costs
($4&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher marketing, administration and research costs ($117&nbsp;million, including costs associated with the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week in 2005, higher
marketing spending in 2006 and the 2005 recovery of a previously written-off account receivable of $16&nbsp;million), higher pre-tax asset impairment and exit costs
($68&nbsp;million, including the $11&nbsp;million intangible asset impairment charge for biscuits assets in Egypt) and higher fixed manufacturing costs ($18&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>2005 compared with 2004  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following discussion compares operating results within each of Kraft's reportable segments for 2005 with 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;North America Beverages.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 4.3% including the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week of
shipments (representing approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of growth), due primarily to refreshment beverages, partially offset by a decline in coffee. Refreshment beverages volume increased,
due primarily to the 2004 acquisition of Veryfine, partially offset by a shift to lower weight sugar-free powdered beverages. In coffee, volume declined due to the impact of
commodity-driven price increases on category consumption, although volume grew in premium brand coffee. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $314&nbsp;million (11.5%), due primarily to higher pricing and lower promotional spending ($158&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing in coffee),
higher volume/mix ($106&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week), the impact of the 2004 Veryfine acquisition ($34&nbsp;million) and favorable currency
($14&nbsp;million). Refreshment beverages net revenues increased, due primarily to expanded distribution of </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Veryfine</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> and new product introductions in
sugar-free powdered beverages. Coffee net revenues increased, due primarily to increased prices and positive mix driven by volume growth in premium brands. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $6&nbsp;million (1.3%), due primarily to higher marketing, administration and research costs ($101&nbsp;million, including higher marketing and
benefit costs, as well as costs associated with the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week) and higher fixed manufacturing costs ($14&nbsp;million), partially offset by favorable volume/mix
($73&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week), lower pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($25&nbsp;million) and higher pricing
($14&nbsp;million, including higher commodity costs). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;North America Cheese&nbsp;&amp; Foodservice.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume decreased 0.1% despite the
53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week of shipments (representing approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of growth), due primarily to the impact of the divestiture of the U.S. yogurt assets, partially
offset by gains in foodservice. In cheese, volume declined due primarily to the impact of the yogurt divestiture, partially offset by gains in natural
cheese, cream cheese, process loaves and cottage cheese. Volume in the foodservice business increased due primarily to the 2004 acquisition of the Veryfine beverage business. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $223&nbsp;million (3.7%), due primarily to favorable volume/mix ($203&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week), favorable
currency ($58&nbsp;million), higher pricing, net of higher promotional spending ($21&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing in late 2004) and the impact of acquisitions
($7&nbsp;million), partially offset by the impact of divestitures ($66&nbsp;million). Cheese net revenues increased, reflecting commodity-driven pricing from 2004 and favorable currency, partially
offset by </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>42</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=43,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=196282,FOLIO='42',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DS4185A.;21',USER='SLYUBOM',CD=';1-MAR-2007;13:02' -->
<A NAME="page_ds4185_1_43"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>increased
promotional spending and the divestiture of the yogurt assets. In foodservice, net revenues increased, due primarily to favorable currency and the impact of the 2004 Veryfine acquisition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income increased $128&nbsp;million (16.1%), due primarily to higher pricing and favorable costs ($77&nbsp;million, net of higher promotional spending), favorable
volume/mix ($62&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week), lower pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($61&nbsp;million) and favorable
currency ($8&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher marketing, administration and research costs ($57&nbsp;million, including higher benefit costs, as well as costs associated with the
53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week) and higher fixed manufacturing costs ($22&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;North America Convenient Meals.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 2.9% including the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week of
shipments (representing approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of growth), due primarily to higher shipments in meats, pizza and meals. Meats volume increased, aided by higher shipments of cold cuts
and new product introductions. Meals volume increased, due primarily to the impact of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week, partially offset by the discontinuation of a product line. In pizza, volume
also increased due primarily to the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week and new product introductions, partially offset by competitive activity. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $274&nbsp;million (6.2%), due to higher volume/mix ($238&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week), higher pricing, net of
increased promotional spending ($20&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing in meats and pizza) and favorable currency ($16&nbsp;million). Meats net revenues increased, due primarily to
higher volume and commodity-driven price increases, partially offset by higher promotional spending. Pizza net revenues increased, driven by positive mix from new products and the impact of
commodity-driven price increases. In meals, net revenues increased due primarily to improved mix from new products, partially offset by the discontinuation of a product line and increased promotional
spending. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $7&nbsp;million (0.9%), due primarily to higher marketing, administration and research costs ($73&nbsp;million, including higher marketing and
benefit costs, as well as costs associated with the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week) and higher fixed manufacturing costs ($31&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher volume/mix ($51&nbsp;million
including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week), lower
pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($28&nbsp;million), higher pricing, net of higher costs ($17&nbsp;million, due primarily to higher commodity driven pricing) and
favorable currency ($4&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;North America Grocery.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume decreased 0.6% due primarily to a decline in Canadian grocery
shipments, despite the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week of shipments (representing approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of growth), and higher enhancers and desserts volume. Canadian grocery volume
declined due primarily to lower vegetable shipments. Enhancers volume increased slightly due primarily to higher shipments of spoonable dressings, partially offset by lower volume in pourable
dressings and barbecue sauce due to increased competitive activity. In desserts, volume increased aided by new product introductions in refrigerated ready-to-eat desserts,
partially offset by declines in dry packaged desserts and the impact of the fruit snacks divestiture. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $15&nbsp;million (0.5%), due primarily to favorable currency ($48&nbsp;million), partially offset by the impact of divestitures ($31&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income decreased $299&nbsp;million (29.2%), due primarily to higher pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($211&nbsp;million),
unfavorable costs ($37&nbsp;million, due primarily to higher commodity costs), higher marketing, administration and research costs ($43&nbsp;million, including higher benefit costs, as well as
costs associated with the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week), lower volume/mix ($8&nbsp;million), the impact of divestitures ($4&nbsp;million) and higher fixed manufacturing costs
($4&nbsp;million), partially offset by favorable currency ($11&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;North America Snacks&nbsp;&amp; Cereals.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 3.3% including the
53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week of shipments (representing approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of growth), as gains in biscuits and cereals were partially offset by a decline in salted snacks. In
biscuits, volume increased due primarily to new product introductions in cookies. Cereals volume increased due primarily to new product introductions and </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>43</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=44,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=777985,FOLIO='43',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DS4185A.;21',USER='SLYUBOM',CD=';1-MAR-2007;13:02' -->
<A NAME="page_ds4185_1_44"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>expanded
distribution in ready-to-eat cereals. In salted snacks, volume declined due to higher commodity-driven pricing on snack nuts and increased competitive activity. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $407&nbsp;million (7.0%), due primarily to higher volume/mix ($325&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week), higher pricing,
net of increased promotional spending ($42&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing in snack nuts and cereals) and favorable currency ($36&nbsp;million). Biscuits net revenues increased,
driven by new product introductions and improved mix. Cereals net revenues also increased, due primarily to new product introductions and higher shipments and pricing of
ready-to-eat cereals. Salted snacks net revenues increased, as lower volume was offset by higher prices. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income increased $145&nbsp;million (18.5%), due primarily to higher volume/mix ($186&nbsp;million including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week),
lower pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($153&nbsp;million) and favorable currency ($6&nbsp;million), partially offset by higher marketing, administration and
research costs ($93&nbsp;million, including higher marketing and benefit costs, as well as costs associated with the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week), unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing
($74&nbsp;million, due primarily to higher commodity costs and increased promotional spending), higher fixed manufacturing costs ($23&nbsp;million) and the net impact of higher implementation
costs associated with the restructuring program ($8&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;European Union.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume decreased 3.7% despite the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week of shipments
(representing approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of growth), due primarily to lower volume in Germany and the divestiture of the U.K. desserts assets in the first quarter of 2005. Beverages
volume declined, driven by lower coffee shipments in Germany, due to commodity-driven price increases. In grocery, volume declined, due to the divestiture of the U.K. desserts assets in the first
quarter of 2005 and lower results in Germany. In snacks, volume declined due primarily to lower shipments of confectionery products in Germany and the U.K. Convenient meals volume declined, due
primarily to lower category performance in the U.K. and lower promotions in Germany. Cheese volume increased due to higher shipments in the U.K. and Italy. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $210&nbsp;million (3.2%), due primarily to favorable currency ($198&nbsp;million) and higher pricing, net of increased promotional spending
($90&nbsp;million, reflecting commodity-driven pricing in coffee), partially offset by the impact of divestitures ($60&nbsp;million) and lower volume/mix ($18&nbsp;million, including the benefit
of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income increased $32&nbsp;million (4.6%), due primarily to net gains on the sale of businesses ($109&nbsp;million), lower pre-tax charges for asset
impairment and exit costs ($53&nbsp;million), favorable currency ($27&nbsp;million), favorable volume/mix ($10&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week), lower
fixed manufacturing costs ($8&nbsp;million) and lower marketing, administration and research costs ($7&nbsp;million, including costs associated with the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week), partially
offset by unfavorable costs, net of higher pricing ($145&nbsp;million, due primarily to higher commodity costs and increased promotional spending), the impact of divestitures ($25&nbsp;million)
and the net impact of higher implementation costs associated with the restructuring program ($12&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Developing Markets, Oceania&nbsp;&amp; North Asia.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Volume increased 0.8% including the
53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week of shipments (representing approximately 2&nbsp;percentage points of growth), due primarily to growth in developing markets, including Russia, Ukraine and Southeast
Asia, partially offset by lower shipments in&nbsp;Egypt and China. In beverages, volume increased due primarily to refreshment beverage gains in the&nbsp;Middle East, Southeast Asia, Argentina and
Puerto Rico, and higher coffee shipments in Russia and&nbsp;Ukraine. Cheese volume increased due to higher shipments in Southeast Asia and the Middle East. In snacks, volume increased, as gains in
confectionery, benefiting from growth in Russia and Ukraine, were partially offset by lower biscuit shipments due to increased competition in China and resizing of biscuit products in Egypt and Latin
America. Grocery volume declined, due primarily to lower shipments in Egypt, Brazil and Central America. In convenient meals, volume declined due primarily to lower shipments in Argentina. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>44</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=45,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=455211,FOLIO='44',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DS4185A.;21',USER='SLYUBOM',CD=';1-MAR-2007;13:02' -->
<A NAME="page_ds4185_1_45"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
revenues increased $502&nbsp;million (13.9%), due primarily to favorable volume/mix ($231&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week), favorable
currency ($163&nbsp;million) and higher pricing, net of increased promotional spending ($124&nbsp;million), partially offset by the impact of divestitures ($17&nbsp;million). Net revenues
increased in several geographies due to growth in Russia, Ukraine and the Middle East, and increased refreshment beverage and cheese shipments in Southeast Asia. Net revenues declined in China, where
the Company faced increased competitive activity in biscuits. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
companies income increased $157&nbsp;million (64.6%), due primarily to favorable volume/mix ($105&nbsp;million, including the benefit of the
53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week), a 2004 equity investment impairment charge related to a joint venture in Turkey ($47&nbsp;million), higher pricing, net of unfavorable costs ($46&nbsp;million,
including increased promotional spending), favorable currency ($32&nbsp;million) and lower pre-tax charges for asset impairment and exit costs ($15&nbsp;million), partially offset by
higher marketing, administration and research costs ($60&nbsp;million, including costs associated with the 53<SUP>rd</SUP>&nbsp;week, partially offset by a $16&nbsp;million recovery of
receivables previously written off) and higher fixed manufacturing costs ($24&nbsp;million). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Financial Review  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Net Cash Provided by Operating Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net cash provided by operating activities was $3.7&nbsp;billion in 2006, $3.5&nbsp;billion in 2005 and $4.0&nbsp;billion in 2004. The increase in 2006
operating cash flows from 2005 is due primarily to the previously discussed tax reimbursement from Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. and higher earnings, partially offset by a
decrease in amounts due to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. and higher pension contributions. The decrease in 2005 operating cash flows from 2004 was due primarily to an increase in income tax payments
(primarily related to the sale of the sugar confectionery business), an increase in the use of cash to fund working capital, due primarily to an increase in cash payments associated with the
restructuring plan, and lower earnings, partially offset by lower pension plan contributions. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Net Cash Provided by (Used in) Investing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;One element of the growth strategy of the Company is to strengthen its brand portfolios and/or expand its geographic reach through disciplined programs of
selective acquisitions and divestitures. The Company is constantly reviewing potential acquisition candidates and from time to time sells businesses to accelerate the shift in its portfolio toward
businesses&#151;whether global, regional or local&#151;that offer the Company a sustainable competitive advantage. The impact of future acquisitions or divestitures could have a material
impact on the Company's cash flows. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2006 and 2004, net cash used by investing activities was $116&nbsp;million and $1.1&nbsp;billion, respectively, as compared with net cash provided by investing activities of
$525&nbsp;million in 2005. During 2006, the Company used cash for investing activities as the proceeds received from the sales of businesses declined by approximately $720&nbsp;million from the
2005 level. During 2006, the Company sold its rice brand and assets, pet snacks brand and assets, industrial coconut assets, certain Canadian assets, a small U.S. biscuit brand and a U.S. coffee
plant. During 2005, the Company sold its sugar confectionery business, fruit snacks assets, U.K. desserts assets, U.S. yogurt assets, a small business in Colombia, a small equity investment in Turkey
and a minor trademark in Mexico. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Capital
expenditures, which were funded by operating activities, were $1.2&nbsp;billion, $1.2&nbsp;billion and $1.0&nbsp;billion in 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. The 2006
capital expenditures were primarily to modernize manufacturing facilities, implement the restructuring program, and support new product and productivity initiatives. In 2007, capital expenditures are
currently expected to be flat to 2006 expenditures, including capital expenditures required for the restructuring program. These expenditures are expected to be funded from operations. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>45</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=46,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=558020,FOLIO='45',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DS4185A.;21',USER='SLYUBOM',CD=';1-MAR-2007;13:02' -->
<A NAME="page_ds4185_1_46"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Net Cash Used in Financing Activities  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2006, net cash of $3.7&nbsp;billion was used in financing activities, compared with $4.0&nbsp;billion during 2005. The decrease in net cash used in
2006 was due primarily to a decrease in net debt repayments, partially offset by an increase in the Company's Class&nbsp;A share repurchases and dividend payments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2005, net cash of $4.0&nbsp;billion was used in financing activities, compared with $3.2&nbsp;billion during 2004. The increase in cash used in 2005 was due primarily to an
increase in the Company's Class&nbsp;A share repurchases and the repayment of debt, partially offset by an increase in amounts due to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. and affiliates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Debt and Liquidity  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Debt.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's total debt, including amounts due to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. and affiliates, was $10.8&nbsp;billion
at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and $11.2&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2005. The Company's debt-to-equity ratio was 0.38 at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005. The
Company's debt-to-capitalization ratio was 0.27 at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company has a Form&nbsp;S-3 shelf registration statement on file with the Securities and Exchange Commission ("SEC") under which the Company may sell debt securities
and/or warrants to purchase debt securities in one or more offerings up to a total amount of $4.0&nbsp;billion. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company had $3.5&nbsp;billion of capacity remaining
under its shelf registration. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, the Company had short-term amounts payable to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. and affiliates of $607&nbsp;million and $652&nbsp;million,
respectively. The amounts payable to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. generally include accrued dividends, taxes and service fees. Interest on intercompany borrowings is based on the applicable London
Interbank Offered Rate. The Company had no long-term amounts payable to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. and affiliates. As discussed under </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Kraft Spin-Off from
Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> within the Description of the Company section above, all intercompany accounts will be settled in cash. However, once items arising from the normal
course of business, such as dividends and tax deposits, are accounted for, the net settlement arising from the spin-off will be insignificant. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company is currently included in the Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. consolidated federal income tax return, and federal income tax contingencies are recorded as liabilities on the balance
sheet of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. Prior to the distribution of Kraft shares, Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. will reimburse the Company in cash for these liabilities, which are approximately
$300&nbsp;million, plus interest. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Credit Ratings.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company's debt ratings by major credit rating agencies were as follows: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On January&nbsp;31, 2007, Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's placed the Company's long-term and short-term credit ratings on CreditWatch with
positive implications. On February&nbsp;20, 2007, following the announcement of a $5&nbsp;billion, two year share repurchase program, Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's maintained its CreditWatch with
positive implications and Moody's placed Kraft's long-term credit ratings under review for possible downgrade. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Credit Lines.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company maintains revolving credit facilities that have historically been used to support the issuance of
commercial paper. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company has a $4.5&nbsp;billion, multi-year revolving credit facility that expires in April&nbsp;2010 on which no amounts were drawn. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>46</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=47,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=45889,FOLIO='46',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DS4185A.;21',USER='SLYUBOM',CD=';1-MAR-2007;13:02' -->
<A NAME="page_ds4185_1_47"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's revolving credit facility, which is for its sole use, requires the maintenance of a minimum net worth of $20.0&nbsp;billion. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company's
net worth was
$28.6&nbsp;billion. The Company expects to continue to meet this covenant. The revolving credit facility does not include any other financial tests, any credit rating triggers or any provisions that
could require the posting of collateral. The Company expects to refinance long-term and short-term debt from time to time. As approximately $1.4&nbsp;billion of the Company's
long-term debt matures during the next twelve months, the Company will evaluate whether and how it will refinance these amounts. The nature and amount of the Company's
long-term and short-term debt and the proportionate amount of each can be expected to vary as a result of future business requirements, market conditions and other factors. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition to the above, certain international subsidiaries of Kraft maintain credit lines to meet the short-term working capital needs of the international businesses.
These credit lines, which amounted to approximately $1.1&nbsp;billion as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, are for the sole use of the Company's international businesses. Borrowings on these lines
amounted to approximately $200&nbsp;million and $400&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively. At December&nbsp;31, 2006 the Company also had approximately
$0.3&nbsp;billion of outstanding short-term debt related to its United Biscuits acquisition discussed in Note&nbsp;6. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Acquisitions</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Off-Balance Sheet Arrangements and Aggregate Contractual Obligations  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has no off-balance sheet arrangements other than the guarantees and contractual obligations that are discussed below. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Guarantees.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As discussed in Note&nbsp;18 to the consolidated financial statements, the Company's third-party guarantees,
which are primarily derived from acquisition and divestiture activities, approximated $21&nbsp;million, of which $8&nbsp;million have no specified expiration dates. Substantially all of the
remainder expire through 2016, with no guarantees expiring during 2007. The Company is required to perform under these guarantees in the event that a third party fails to make contractual payments or
achieve performance measures. The Company has a liability of $16&nbsp;million on its consolidated balance sheet at December&nbsp;31, 2006, relating to these guarantees. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, at December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company was contingently liable for $189&nbsp;million of guarantees related to its own performance. These include surety bonds related to
dairy commodity purchases and guarantees related to the payment of customs duties and taxes, and letters of credit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Guarantees
do not have, and are not expected to have, a significant impact on the Company's liquidity. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>47</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Amounts
represent the expected cash payments of the Company's long-term debt and do not include unamortized bond premiums or discounts.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Amounts
represent the expected cash payments of the Company's interest expense on its long-term debt. Due to the complex nature of forecasting expected variable rate
interest payments on the Company's insignificant balance of variable rate long-term debt, those amounts are not included in the table.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(3)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Operating
leases represent the minimum rental commitments under non-cancelable operating leases. The Company has no significant capital lease obligations.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(4)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Purchase
obligations for inventory and production costs (such as raw materials, indirect materials and supplies, packaging, co-manufacturing arrangements, storage and
distribution) are commitments for projected needs to be utilized in the normal course of business. Other purchase obligations include commitments for marketing, advertising, capital expenditures,
information technology and professional services. Arrangements are considered purchase obligations if a contract specifies all significant terms, including fixed or minimum quantities to be purchased,
a pricing structure and approximate timing of the transaction. Most arrangements are cancelable without a significant penalty, and with short notice (usually 30&nbsp;days). Any amounts reflected on
the consolidated balance sheet as accounts payable and accrued liabilities are excluded from the table above.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(5)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Other
long-term liabilities primarily consist of postretirement health care costs. The following long-term liabilities included on the consolidated balance
sheet are excluded from the table above: accrued pension costs, income taxes, minority interest, insurance accruals and other accruals. The Company is unable to estimate the timing of the payments (or
contributions in the case of accrued pension costs) for these items. Currently, the Company anticipates making U.S. pension contributions of approximately $16&nbsp;million in 2007 and
non-U.S. pension contributions of approximately $157&nbsp;million in 2007, based on current tax law (as discussed in Note&nbsp;15 to the consolidated financial statements). </FONT></DD></DL>
<BR>
<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="CENTER" WIDTH="120">

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company believes that its cash from operations and existing credit facility will provide sufficient liquidity to meet its working capital needs (including the cash requirements of
the restructuring program), planned capital expenditures, future contractual obligations and payment of its anticipated quarterly dividends. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>48</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=49,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=253015,FOLIO='48',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DS4185A.;21',USER='SLYUBOM',CD=';1-MAR-2007;13:02' -->
<A NAME="page_ds4185_1_49"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Equity and Dividends  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In December&nbsp;2004, the Company commenced repurchasing shares under a two-year $1.5&nbsp;billion Class&nbsp;A common stock repurchase program
authorized by its Board of Directors. In March&nbsp;2006, the Company completed the program, acquiring 49.1&nbsp;million Class&nbsp;A shares at an average price of $30.57 per share. In
March&nbsp;2006, the Company's Board of Directors authorized a new share repurchase program to repurchase up to $2.0&nbsp;billion of the Company's Class&nbsp;A common stock. This new program is
expected to run through 2008. During 2006 and 2005, the Company repurchased 8.5&nbsp;million and 39.2&nbsp;million shares, respectively, of its Class&nbsp;A common stock under its
$1.5&nbsp;billion repurchase program at a cost of $250&nbsp;million and $1.2&nbsp;billion, respectively. In addition, as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company repurchased 30.2&nbsp;million
shares of its Class&nbsp;A common stock, under its new $2.0&nbsp;billion authority, at an aggregate cost of $1.0&nbsp;billion, bringing total repurchases for 2006 to 38.7&nbsp;million shares
for $1.2&nbsp;billion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
February 2007, the Company announced that the Board of Directors authorized a stock repurchase plan pursuant to which the Company may repurchase shares of the Company's Class A common
stock having an aggregate value up to $5&nbsp;billion through March 2009. The repurchase program will become effective immediately following the distribution of the approximately 89% of
the Company's outstanding shares owned by Altria Group Inc. The program does not obligate the Company to acquire any particular amount of Class A common stock, it replaces the existing share
repurchase program, and it may be suspended at any time at the Company's discretion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
discussed in Note&nbsp;11 to the consolidated financial statements, during 2006 and 2005, the Company granted approximately 4.8&nbsp;million and 4.2&nbsp;million restricted
Class&nbsp;A shares, respectively, to eligible U.S.-based employees, and during 2006 and 2005, also issued to eligible non-U.S. employees rights to receive approximately
2.0&nbsp;million and 1.8&nbsp;million Class&nbsp;A equivalent shares, respectively. The market value per restricted share or right was $29.16 and $33.26 on the dates of the 2006 and 2005 grants,
respectively. Restrictions on most of the stock and rights granted in 2006 lapse in the first quarter of 2009, while restrictions on grants in 2005 lapse in the first quarter of 2008. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective
January&nbsp;1, 2006, the Company adopted the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (Revised 2004), "Share-Based Payment," ("SFAS No.&nbsp;123(R)") using the modified
prospective method, which requires measurement of compensation cost for all stock-based awards at fair value on date of grant and recognition of compensation over the service periods for awards
expected to vest. The fair value of restricted stock and rights to receive shares of stock is determined based on the number of shares granted and the market value at date of grant. The fair value of
stock options is determined using a modified Black-Scholes methodology. The impact of adoption was not material. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the number of shares to be issued upon exercise of
outstanding stock options and vesting of non-U.S. rights to receive equivalent shares (excluding any options or rights to be issued as part of the Company's spin-off from
Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.) was 17.8&nbsp;million or 1.1% of total Class&nbsp;A and Class&nbsp;B shares outstanding. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Dividends
paid in 2006 and 2005 were $1,562&nbsp;million and $1,437&nbsp;million, respectively, an increase of 8.7%, reflecting a higher dividend rate in 2006, partially offset by a
lower number of shares outstanding as a result of Class&nbsp;A share repurchases. During the third quarter of 2006, the Company's Board of Directors approved an 8.7% increase in the current
quarterly dividend rate to $0.25 per share on its Class&nbsp;A and Class&nbsp;B common stock. As a result, the present annualized dividend rate is $1.00 per common share. The declaration of
dividends is subject to the discretion of the Company's Board of Directors and will depend on various factors, including the Company's net earnings, financial condition, cash requirements, future
prospects and other factors deemed relevant by the Company's Board of Directors. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
January&nbsp;31, 2007, the Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. Board of Directors announced that Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. plans to spin off all of its remaining interest (89.0%) in the
Company on a pro rata basis to Altria </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>49</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=10,SEQ=50,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=505637,FOLIO='49',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DS4185A.;21',USER='SLYUBOM',CD=';1-MAR-2007;13:02' -->
<A NAME="page_ds4185_1_50"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Group,&nbsp;Inc.
stockholders in a tax-free transaction. See </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Kraft Spin-Off from Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> within the
Description of the Company section above for further details. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Market Risk  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company operates globally, with manufacturing and sales facilities in various locations around the world, and utilizes certain financial instruments to manage
its foreign currency and commodity exposures. Derivative financial instruments are used by the Company, principally to reduce exposures to market risks resulting from fluctuations in foreign exchange
rates and commodity prices by creating offsetting exposures. The Company is not a party to leveraged derivatives and, by policy, does not use financial instruments for speculative purposes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, ineffectiveness related to cash flow hedges was not material. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company was hedging
forecasted transactions for periods not exceeding the next fifteen months, and expects substantially all amounts reported in accumulated other comprehensive earnings (losses) at December&nbsp;31,
2006 to be reclassified to the consolidated statement of earnings within the next twelve months. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Foreign Exchange Rates.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company uses forward foreign exchange contracts and foreign currency options to mitigate its
exposure to changes in exchange rates from third-party and intercompany actual and forecasted transactions. Substantially all of the Company's derivative financial instruments are effective as hedges.
The primary currencies to which the Company is exposed, based on the size and location of its businesses, include the euro, Swiss franc, British pound and Canadian dollar. At December&nbsp;31, 2006
and 2005, the Company had foreign exchange option and forward contracts with aggregate notional amounts of $2.6&nbsp;billion and $2.2&nbsp;billion, respectively. The effective portion of
unrealized gains and losses associated with forward and option contracts is deferred as a component of accumulated other comprehensive earnings (losses) until the underlying hedged transactions are
reported on the Company's consolidated statement of earnings. In 2007, the Company also anticipates entering into additional hedging instruments to mitigate its exposure to changes in exchange rates
relating to distributions contemplated in advance of the </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Kraft Spin-Off from Altria Group, Inc.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, as referred to within the Description of the Company
section above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Commodities.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is exposed to price risk related to forecasted purchases of certain commodities used as raw
materials by its businesses. Accordingly, the Company uses commodity forward contracts as cash flow hedges, primarily for coffee, milk, sugar and cocoa. In general, commodity forward contracts qualify
for the normal purchase exception under SFAS No.&nbsp;133 and are, therefore, not subject to the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;133. In addition, commodity futures and options are also used to hedge
the price of certain commodities, including milk, coffee, cocoa, wheat, corn, sugar, soybean oil, natural gas and heating oil. For qualifying contracts, the effective portion of unrealized gains and
losses on commodity futures and option contracts is deferred as a component of accumulated other comprehensive earnings (losses) and is recognized as a component of cost of sales in the Company's
consolidated statement of earnings when the related inventory is sold. Unrealized gains or losses on net commodity positions were immaterial at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005. At
December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, the Company had net long commodity positions of $533&nbsp;million and $521&nbsp;million, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Value at Risk.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company uses a value at risk ("VAR") computation to estimate the potential one-day loss in the
fair value of its interest rate-sensitive financial instruments and to estimate the potential one-day loss in pre-tax earnings of its foreign currency and commodity
price-sensitive derivative financial instruments. The VAR computation includes the Company's debt; short-term investments; foreign currency forwards, swaps and options; and commodity
futures, forwards and options. Anticipated transactions, foreign currency trade payables and receivables, and net investments in foreign subsidiaries, which the foregoing instruments are intended to
hedge, were excluded from the computation. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>50</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=11,SEQ=51,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=372549,FOLIO='50',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DS4185A.;21',USER='SLYUBOM',CD=';1-MAR-2007;13:02' -->
<A NAME="page_ds4185_1_51"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
VAR estimates were made assuming normal market conditions, using a 95% confidence interval. The Company used a "variance/co-variance" model to determine the observed
interrelationships between movements in interest rates and various currencies. These interrelationships were determined by observing interest rate and forward currency rate movements over the
preceding quarter for the calculation of VAR amounts at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, and over each of the four preceding quarters for the calculation of average VAR amounts during each year. The
values of foreign currency and commodity options do not change on a one-to-one basis with the underlying currency or commodity, and were valued accordingly in the VAR
computation. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
estimated potential one-day loss in fair value of the Company's interest rate-sensitive instruments, primarily debt, under normal market conditions and the
estimated potential one-day loss in pre-tax earnings from foreign currency and commodity instruments under normal market conditions, as calculated in the VAR model, were as
follows (in&nbsp;millions): </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This VAR computation is a risk analysis tool designed to statistically estimate the maximum probable daily loss from adverse movements in interest rates, foreign
currency rates and commodity prices under normal market conditions. The computation does not purport to represent actual losses in fair value or earnings to be incurred by the Company, nor does it
consider the effect of favorable changes in market rates. The Company cannot predict actual future movements in such market rates and does not present these VAR results to be indicative of future
movements in such market rates or to be representative of any actual impact that future changes in market rates may have on its future results of operations or financial position. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>New Accounting Standards  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See Notes&nbsp;2, 15 and 17 to the consolidated financial statements for a discussion of new accounting standards. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Contingencies  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See Note&nbsp;18 to the consolidated financial statements for a discussion of contingencies. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ds4185_item_7a._quantitative_and_qual__ite02650"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ds4185_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item&nbsp;7A.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk.    <BR>    </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See paragraphs captioned "Market Risk" and "Value at Risk" in Item&nbsp;7 above. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>51</FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="du4185_item_8._financial_statements_and_supplementary_data."> </A>
<A NAME="toc_du4185_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>Item 8.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Financial Statements and Supplementary Data.    <BR>    </I></B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="du4185_report_of_management_on_intern__rep02683"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_du4185_2"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>REPORT OF MANAGEMENT ON INTERNAL CONTROL OVER FINANCIAL REPORTING    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management of the Company is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in
Rules&nbsp;13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. The Company's internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide
reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in
the United States of America. The Company's internal control over financial reporting includes those written policies and procedures that: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>pertain
to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the Company;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>provide
reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States of America;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>provide
reasonable assurance that receipts and expenditures of the Company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the Company;
and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>provide
reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of assets that could have a material effect on the
consolidated financial statements. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Internal
control over financial reporting includes the controls themselves, monitoring and internal auditing practices and actions taken to correct deficiencies as identified. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Because
of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements. Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future
periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management
assessed the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2006. Management based this assessment on criteria for
effective internal control over financial reporting described in </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Internal Control&#151;Integrated Framework</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> issued by the Committee of Sponsoring
Organizations of the Treadway Commission ("COSO"). Management's assessment included an evaluation of the design of the Company's internal control over financial reporting and testing of the
operational effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial reporting. Management reviewed the results of its assessment with the Audit Committee of the Company's Board of Directors. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Based
on this assessment, management determined that, as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company maintained effective internal control over financial reporting. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;PricewaterhouseCoopers
LLP, independent registered public accounting firm, who audited and reported on the consolidated financial statements of the Company included in this report, has
audited our management's assessment of the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>February&nbsp;5,
2007 </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>52</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=53,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=776881,FOLIO='52',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DU4185A.;12',USER='EYOUNG',CD='28-FEB-2007;08:44' -->
<A NAME="page_du4185_1_53"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="du4185_report_of_independent_r__du402315"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_du4185_3"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>To
the Board of Directors and Shareholders of Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc.: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
have completed integrated audits of Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc.'s consolidated financial statements and of its internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, in
accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). Our opinions, based on our audits, are presented below. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Consolidated financial statements  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In our opinion, the accompanying consolidated balance sheets and the related consolidated statements of earnings, shareholders' equity, and cash flows, present
fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc. and its subsidiaries at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, and the results of their operations and their cash flows
for each of the three years in the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America. These financial statements are the
responsibility of Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc.'s management. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits. We conducted our audits of these statements in
accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether
the financial statements are free of material misstatement. An audit of financial statements includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial
statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, and evaluating the overall financial statement presentation. We believe that our audits provide a
reasonable basis for our opinion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
discussed in Note&nbsp;15 to the consolidated financial statements, Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc. changed the manner in which it accounts for pension, postretirement and postemployment
plans in fiscal 2006. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Internal control over financial reporting  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Also, in our opinion, management's assessment, included in the Report of Management on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting dated February&nbsp;5, 2007,
that Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc. maintained effective internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 based on criteria established in </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Internal
Control&#151;Integrated Framework</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ("COSO"), is fairly stated, in all material respects,
based on those criteria. Furthermore, in our opinion, Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December&nbsp;31, 2006,
based on criteria established in </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Internal Control&#151;Integrated Framework</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> issued by the COSO. Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc.'s management is
responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting. Our responsibility is to
express opinions on management's assessment and on the effectiveness of Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc.'s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit. We conducted our audit of internal
control over financial reporting in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain
reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects. An audit of internal control over financial reporting includes obtaining
an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, evaluating management's assessment, testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control, and performing
such other procedures as we consider necessary in the circumstances. We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinions. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A
company's internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of
financial statements for </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>53</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=54,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=311496,FOLIO='53',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]DU4185A.;12',USER='EYOUNG',CD='28-FEB-2007;08:44' -->
<A NAME="page_du4185_1_54"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>external
purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles. A company's internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (i)&nbsp;pertain to
the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (ii)&nbsp;provide reasonable assurance that
transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are
being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (iii)&nbsp;provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized
acquisition, use, or disposition of the company's assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Because
of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements. Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future
periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>/s/&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2>PRICEWATERHOUSECOOPERS LLP</FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Chicago,
Illinois<BR>
February&nbsp;5, 2007 </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>54</FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=59,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=516819,FOLIO='58',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]EA4185B.;10',USER='ABLIJDE',CD='27-FEB-2007;16:14' -->
