<!-- TOC_END -->
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ec4185_kraft_foods_inc._and_subsidiar__kra03026"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ec4185_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>KRAFT FOODS&nbsp;INC. and SUBSIDIARIES    <BR>    <BR>    NOTES to CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;1.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Background and Basis of Presentation:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Background:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc. ("Kraft") was incorporated in 2000 in the Commonwealth of Virginia. Kraft, through its subsidiaries (Kraft and its subsidiaries are
hereinafter referred to as the "Company"), is engaged in the manufacture and sale of packaged foods and beverages in the United States, Canada, Europe, Latin America, Asia Pacific and Middle East and
Africa. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior
to June&nbsp;13, 2001, the Company was a wholly-owned subsidiary of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. On June&nbsp;13, 2001, the Company completed an initial public offering ("IPO") of
280,000,000 shares of its Class&nbsp;A common stock at a price of $31.00 per share. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. held 98.5% of the combined voting power of the Company's
outstanding capital stock and owned 89.0% of the outstanding shares of the Company's capital stock. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
further discussed in Note&nbsp;20. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Subsequent Event</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, on January&nbsp;31, 2007, Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s Board of Directors
approved a tax-free distribution to its stockholders of all of its interest in the Company. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
June&nbsp;2005, the Company sold substantially all of its sugar confectionery business for pre-tax proceeds of approximately $1.4&nbsp;billion. The Company has
reflected the results of its sugar confectionery business prior to the closing date as discontinued operations on the consolidated statements of earnings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
October&nbsp;2005, the Company announced that, effective January&nbsp;1, 2006, its Canadian business would be realigned to better integrate it into the Company's North American
business by product category. Beginning in the first quarter of 2006, the operating results of the Canadian business were being reported throughout the North American food segments. In addition, in
the first quarter of 2006, the Company's international businesses were realigned to reflect the reorganization announced within Europe in November&nbsp;2005. The two revised international segments,
which are reflected in these consolidated financial statements and notes, are European Union; and Developing Markets, Oceania&nbsp;&amp; North Asia, the latter to reflect the Company's increased
management focus on developing markets. Accordingly, prior period segment results have been restated. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Basis of presentation:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The consolidated financial statements include Kraft, as well as its wholly-owned and majority-owned subsidiaries. Investments in which the Company exercises
significant influence (20%&#151;50% ownership interest) are accounted for under the equity method of accounting. Investments in which the Company has an ownership interest of less than 20%, or
does not exercise significant influence, are accounted for by the cost method of accounting. All intercompany transactions and balances between and among Kraft's subsidiaries have been eliminated.
Transactions between any of the Company's businesses and Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. and its affiliates are included in these financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make estimates and assumptions
that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, the disclosure of contingent liabilities at the dates of the financial statements and the reported amounts of net revenues and expenses
during the reporting periods. Significant estimates and assumptions include, among other things, pension and benefit plan assumptions, lives and valuation assumptions of goodwill and other intangible
assets, marketing programs and income taxes. Actual results could differ from those estimates. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>59</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=60,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=222922,FOLIO='59',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]EC4185A.;16',USER='ABLIJDE',CD='27-FEB-2007;16:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ec4185_1_60"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's operating subsidiaries generally report year-end results as of the Saturday closest to the end of each year. This resulted in fifty-three weeks of operating
results in
the Company's consolidated statement of earnings for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, versus fifty-two weeks for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Classification
of certain prior year balance sheet amounts related to pension plans have been reclassified to conform with the current year's presentation. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;2.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Summary of Significant Accounting Policies:  </B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Cash and cash equivalents:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash equivalents include demand deposits with banks and all highly liquid investments with original maturities of three months or less. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Depreciation, amortization and goodwill valuation:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Property, plant and equipment are stated at historical cost and depreciated by the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets.
Machinery and equipment are depreciated over periods ranging from 3 to 20&nbsp;years, and buildings and building improvements over periods up to 40&nbsp;years. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Definite
life intangible assets are amortized over their estimated useful lives. The Company is required to conduct an annual review of goodwill and intangible assets for potential
impairment. Goodwill impairment testing requires a comparison between the carrying value and fair value of each reporting unit. If the carrying value exceeds the fair value, goodwill is considered
impaired. The amount of impairment loss is measured as the difference between the carrying value and implied fair value of goodwill, which is determined using discounted cash flows. Impairment testing
for non-amortizable intangible assets requires a comparison between the fair value and carrying value of the intangible asset. If the carrying value exceeds fair value, the intangible
asset is considered impaired and is reduced to fair value. During the first quarter of 2006, the Company completed its annual review of goodwill and intangible assets and recorded non-cash
pre-tax charges of $24&nbsp;million related to an intangible asset impairment for biscuits assets in Egypt and hot cereal assets in the United States. Additionally, in 2006, as part of
the sale of its pet snacks brand and assets, the Company recorded non-cash pre-tax asset impairment charges of $86&nbsp;million, which included the write-off of a
portion of the associated goodwill and intangible assets of $25&nbsp;million and $55&nbsp;million, respectively, as well as $6&nbsp;million of asset write-downs. In January&nbsp;2007, the
Company announced the sale of its hot cereal assets and trademarks. In recognition of the anticipated sale, the Company recorded a pre-tax asset impairment charge of $69&nbsp;million in
2006 for these assets, which included the write-off of a portion of the associated goodwill and intangible assets of $15&nbsp;million and $52&nbsp;million, respectively, as well as
$2&nbsp;million of asset write-downs. During the first quarter of 2005, the Company completed its annual review of goodwill and intangible assets and no impairment charges resulted from this review.
However, as part of the sale of certain Canadian assets and two brands, the Company recorded total non-cash pre-tax asset impairment charges of $269&nbsp;million in 2005,
which included impairment of goodwill and intangible assets of $13&nbsp;million and $118&nbsp;million, respectively, as well as $138&nbsp;million of asset write-downs. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>60</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<TD WIDTH="9%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>10,577</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="12%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>61</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=2><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Non-amortizable
intangible assets consist substantially of brand names purchased through the Nabisco acquisition. Amortizable intangible assets consist primarily of certain
trademark licenses and non-compete agreements. Amortization expense for intangible assets was $7&nbsp;million, $10&nbsp;million and $11&nbsp;million for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. Amortization expense for each of the next five years is currently estimated to be approximately $10&nbsp;million or less. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
movement in goodwill and gross carrying amount of intangible assets is as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
increase in goodwill and intangible assets from acquisitions is related to preliminary allocations of purchase price for the Company's acquisition of certain United Biscuits
operations and Nabisco trademarks as discussed in Note&nbsp;6. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Acquisitions</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. The allocations are based upon preliminary estimates and assumptions and
are subject to revision when appraisals are finalized, which is expected to occur during the first half of 2007. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>61</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=62,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=311120,FOLIO='61',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]EC4185A.;16',USER='ABLIJDE',CD='27-FEB-2007;16:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ec4185_1_62"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Environmental costs:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is subject to laws and regulations relating to the protection of the environment. The Company provides for expenses associated with environmental
remediation obligations on an undiscounted basis when such amounts are probable and can be reasonably estimated. Such accruals are adjusted as new information develops or circumstances change. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;While
it is not possible to quantify with certainty the potential impact of actions regarding environmental remediation and compliance efforts that the Company may undertake in the
future, in the opinion of management, environmental remediation and compliance costs, before taking into account any recoveries from third parties, will not have a material adverse effect on the
Company's consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Foreign currency translation:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company translates the results of operations of its foreign subsidiaries using average exchange rates during each period, whereas balance sheet accounts are
translated using exchange rates at the end of each period. Currency translation adjustments are recorded as a component of shareholders' equity. Transaction gains and losses are recorded in the
consolidated statements of earnings and were not significant for any of the periods presented. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Guarantees:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company accounts for guarantees in accordance with Financial Accounting Standards Board ("FASB") Interpretation No.&nbsp;45, "Guarantor's Accounting and
Disclosure Requirements for Guarantees, Including Indirect Guarantees of Indebtedness of Others." Interpretation No.&nbsp;45 requires the disclosure of certain guarantees and the recognition of a
liability for the fair value of the obligation of qualifying guarantee activities. See Note&nbsp;18. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Contingencies</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> for a further discussion of
guarantees. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Hedging instruments:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Derivative financial instruments are recorded at fair value on the consolidated balance sheets as either assets or liabilities. Changes in the fair value of
derivatives are recorded each period either in accumulated other comprehensive earnings (losses) or in earnings, depending on whether a derivative is designated and effective as part of a hedge
transaction and, if it is, the type of hedge transaction. Gains and losses on derivative instruments reported in accumulated other comprehensive earnings (losses) are reclassified to the consolidated
statement of earnings in the periods in which operating results are affected by the hedged item. Cash flows from hedging instruments are classified in the same manner as the affected hedged item in
the consolidated statements of cash flows. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Impairment of long-lived assets:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company reviews long-lived assets, including amortizable intangible assets, for impairment whenever events or changes in business circumstances
indicate that the carrying amount of the assets may not be fully recoverable. The Company performs undiscounted operating cash flow analyses to determine if an impairment exists. For purposes of
recognition and measurement of an impairment for assets held for use, the Company groups assets and liabilities at the lowest level for which cash flows are separately identifiable. If an impairment
is determined to exist, any related impairment loss is calculated based on fair value. Impairment losses on assets to be disposed of, if any, are based on the estimated proceeds to be received, less
costs of disposal. During 2006, the Company recorded non-cash pre-tax asset impairment charges of $245&nbsp;million related to its </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Tassimo</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> hot beverage business. The charges are included in asset
impairment and exit costs in the consolidated statement of earnings. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>62</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=63,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=128087,FOLIO='62',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]EC4185A.;16',USER='ABLIJDE',CD='27-FEB-2007;16:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ec4185_1_63"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Income taxes:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company accounts for income taxes in accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards ("SFAS") No.&nbsp;109, "Accounting for Income Taxes." The
U.S. accounts of the Company are included in the consolidated federal income tax return of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. Income taxes are generally computed on a separate company basis. To the extent that
foreign tax credits, capital losses and other credits generated by the Company, which cannot currently be utilized on a separate company basis, are utilized in Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s consolidated
federal income tax return, the benefit is recognized in the calculation of the Company's provision for income taxes. Based on the Company's current estimate, this benefit is calculated to be
approximately $195&nbsp;million, $225&nbsp;million and $70&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. The amounts in 2005 and 2006 include dividend
repatriations and the impact of certain legal entity reorganizations. The Company makes payments to, or is reimbursed by, Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. for the tax effects resulting from its inclusion in
Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s consolidated federal income tax return, including current taxes payable and net changes in tax provisions. The Company is assessing opportunities to mitigate the loss of
tax benefits upon Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s distribution of its Kraft shares, and currently estimates the annual amount of lost tax benefits to be in the range of $50&nbsp;million to
$75&nbsp;million. Significant judgment is required in determining income tax provisions and in evaluating tax positions. The Company establishes additional provisions for income taxes when, despite
the belief that existing tax positions are fully supportable, there remain certain positions that are likely to be challenged and that may not be sustained on review by tax authorities. The Company
evaluates and potentially adjusts these provisions in light of changing facts and circumstances. The consolidated tax provision includes the impact of changes to accruals that are deemed necessary. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
July&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;48, "Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes&#151;an interpretation of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;109" ("FIN
48"), which will become effective for the Company on January&nbsp;1, 2007. The Interpretation prescribes a recognition threshold and a measurement attribute for the financial statement recognition
and measurement of tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return. For those benefits to be recognized, a tax position must be more-likely-than-not to
be sustained upon examination by taxing authorities. The amount recognized is measured as the largest amount of benefit that is greater than 50&nbsp;percent likely of being realized upon ultimate
settlement. The adoption of FIN 48 will result in an increase to shareholders' equity as of January&nbsp;1, 2007 of approximately $200&nbsp;million to $225&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Inventories:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Inventories are stated at the lower of cost or market. The last-in, first-out ("LIFO") method is used to cost a majority of domestic
inventories. The cost of other inventories is principally determined by the average cost method. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company adopted the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;151, "Inventory Costs" prospectively as of January&nbsp;1, 2006. SFAS No.&nbsp;151 requires that abnormal idle facility expense,
spoilage, freight and handling costs be recognized as current-period charges. In addition, SFAS No.&nbsp;151 requires that allocation of fixed production overhead costs to inventories be based on
the normal capacity of the production facility. The effect of adoption did not have a material impact on the Company's consolidated results of operations, financial position or cash flows. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Marketing costs:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company promotes its products with advertising, consumer incentives and trade promotions. Such programs include, but are not limited to, discounts, coupons,
rebates, in-store display incentives and volume-based incentives. Advertising costs are expensed as incurred. Consumer incentive and trade promotion activities are recorded as a reduction
of revenues based on amounts estimated as </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>63</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=64,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=341163,FOLIO='63',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]EC4185A.;16',USER='ABLIJDE',CD='27-FEB-2007;16:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ec4185_1_64"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>being
due to customers and consumers at the end of a period, based principally on historical utilization and redemption rates. For interim reporting purposes, advertising and consumer incentive
expenses are charged to operations as a percentage of volume, based on estimated volume and related expense for the full year. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Revenue recognition:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company recognizes revenues, net of sales incentives and including shipping and handling charges billed to customers, upon shipment or delivery of goods when
title and risk of loss pass to customers. Shipping and handling costs are classified as part of cost of sales. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Software costs:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company capitalizes certain computer software and software development costs incurred in connection with developing or obtaining computer software for
internal use. Capitalized software costs are included in property, plant and equipment on the consolidated balance sheets and amortized on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful
lives of the software, which do not exceed five years. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Stock-based compensation:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective January&nbsp;1, 2006, the Company adopted the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;123 (Revised 2004), "Share-Based Payment," ("SFAS No.&nbsp;123(R)")
using the modified prospective method, which requires measurement of compensation cost for all stock-based awards at fair value on date of grant and recognition of compensation over the service
periods for awards expected to vest. The fair value of restricted stock and rights to receive shares of stock is determined based on the number of shares granted and the market value at date of grant.
The fair value of stock options is determined using a modified Black-Scholes methodology. The impact of adoption was not material. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;123(R) resulted in a cumulative effect gain of $6&nbsp;million, which is net of $3&nbsp;million in taxes, in the consolidated statement of earnings
for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. This gain resulted from the impact of estimating future forfeitures on restricted stock and rights to receive shares of stock in the determination of
periodic expense for unvested awards, rather than recording forfeitures only when they occur. The gross cumulative effect was recorded in marketing, administration and research costs for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company previously applied the recognition and measurement principles of Accounting Principles Board Opinion No.&nbsp;25, "Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees," ("APB 25") and
provided the pro forma disclosures required by SFAS No.&nbsp;123, "Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation" ("SFAS No.&nbsp;123"). No compensation expense for employee stock options was reflected
in net earnings in 2005 and 2004, as all stock options granted under those plans had an exercise price equal to the market value of the common stock on the date of the grant. Historical consolidated
statements of earnings already include the compensation expense for restricted stock and rights to receive shares of stock. The following table illustrates the effect on net earnings and earnings per
share ("EPS") if the Company had applied the fair value recognition provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;123 to measure compensation </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>64</FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company elected to calculate the initial pool of tax benefits resulting from tax deductions in excess of the stock-based employee compensation expense recognized in the statement of
earnings under FASB Staff Position 123(R)-3, "Transition Election Related to Accounting for the Tax Effects of Share-Based Payment Awards." Under SFAS No.&nbsp;123(R), tax shortfalls
occur when actual tax deductible compensation expense is less than cumulative stock-based compensation expense recognized in the financial statements. Tax shortfalls of $8&nbsp;million were
recognized for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, and were recorded in additional paid-in capital. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;3.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Asset Impairment, Exit and Implementation Costs:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Restructuring Program:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January&nbsp;2004, the Company announced a three-year restructuring program with the objectives of leveraging the Company's global scale,
realigning and lowering its cost structure, and optimizing capacity utilization. In January&nbsp;2006, the Company announced plans to expand its restructuring efforts through 2008. The entire
restructuring program is expected to result in $3.0&nbsp;billion in pre-tax charges reflecting asset disposals, severance and implementation costs. The decline of $700&nbsp;million
from the $3.7&nbsp;billion in pre-tax charges previously announced was due primarily to lower than projected severance costs, the cancellation of an initiative to generate sales
efficiencies, and the sale of one plant that was originally planned to be closed. As part of this program, the Company anticipates the closure of up to 40 facilities and the elimination of
approximately 14,000 positions. Approximately $1.9&nbsp;billion of the $3.0&nbsp;billion in pre-tax charges are expected to require cash payments. Pre-tax restructuring
program charges, including implementation costs for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004 were $673&nbsp;million, $297&nbsp;million and $641&nbsp;million, respectively. Total
pre-tax restructuring charges incurred since the inception of the program in January&nbsp;2004 were $1.6&nbsp;billion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2006, the Company announced a seven-year, $1.7&nbsp;billion agreement to receive information technology services from Electronic Data Systems ("EDS"). The agreement,
which includes data centers, web hosting, telecommunications and IT workplace services, began on June&nbsp;1, 2006. Pursuant to the agreement, approximately 670 employees, who provided certain IT
support to the Company, were transitioned to EDS. As a result of the agreement, in 2006 the Company incurred pre-tax asset impairment and exit costs of $51&nbsp;million and
implementation costs of $56&nbsp;million related to the transition. These costs were included in the pre-tax restructuring program charges discussed above. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>65</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=66,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=146538,FOLIO='65',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]EC4185A.;16',USER='ABLIJDE',CD='27-FEB-2007;16:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ec4185_1_66"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Restructuring Costs:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2006, 2005 and 2004, pre-tax charges under the restructuring program of $578&nbsp;million, $210&nbsp;million and $583&nbsp;million,
respectively, were recorded as asset impairment and exit costs on the consolidated statements of earnings. These pre-tax charges resulted from the announcement of the closing of 27 plants
since January&nbsp;2004, of which 8 occurred in 2006, the continuation of a number of workforce reduction programs, and the termination of co-manufacturing agreements in 2004.
Approximately $332&nbsp;million of the pre-tax charges incurred during 2006 will require cash payments. </FONT></P>

restructuring liability activity for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, was as follows: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Severance
costs in the above schedule, which relate to the workforce reduction programs, include the cost of related benefits. Specific programs announced since 2004, as part of the
overall restructuring program, will result in the elimination of approximately 9,800 positions. At
December&nbsp;31, 2006, approximately 8,400 of these positions have been eliminated. Asset write-downs relate to the impairment of assets caused by the plant closings and related activity. Other
costs incurred relate primarily to contract termination costs associated with the plant closings and the termination of leasing agreements. Severance costs taken against assets relate to incremental
pension costs, which reduce prepaid pension assets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Implementation Costs:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2006, 2005 and 2004, the Company recorded pre-tax implementation costs associated with the restructuring program. These costs include the
discontinuance of certain product lines and incremental costs related to the integration and streamlining of functions and closure of facilities. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>66</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Asset Impairment Charges:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2006, the Company sold its pet snacks brand and assets, and recorded tax expense of $57&nbsp;million and incurred a pre-tax asset impairment
charge of $86&nbsp;million in 2006 in recognition of this sale. In January&nbsp;2007, the Company announced the sale of its hot cereal assets and trademarks. In recognition of the anticipated
sale, the Company recorded a pre-tax asset impairment charge of $69&nbsp;million in 2006 for these assets. These pre-tax asset impairment charges, which included the
write-off of a portion of the associated goodwill, and intangible and fixed assets, were recorded as asset impairment and exit costs on the consolidated statement of earnings. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2006, the Company completed its annual review of goodwill and intangible assets, and recorded non-cash pre-tax charges of $24&nbsp;million related to an
intangible asset impairment for biscuits assets in Egypt and hot cereal assets in the United States. Also during 2006, the Company re-evaluated the business model for its </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Tassimo</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> hot beverage system,
the revenues of which lagged the Company's projections. This evaluation resulted in a $245&nbsp;million
non-cash pre-tax asset impairment charge related to lower utilization of existing manufacturing capacity. These charges were recorded as asset impairment and exit costs on the
consolidated statement of earnings. In addition, the Company anticipates that the impairment will result in related cash expenditures of approximately $3&nbsp;million, primarily related to
decommissioning of idle production lines. During 2005, the Company completed its annual review of goodwill and intangible assets and no charges resulted from this review. During 2004, the Company
recorded a $29&nbsp;million non-cash pre-tax charge related to an intangible asset impairment for a small confectionery business in the United States and certain brands in
Mexico. A portion of this charge, $17&nbsp;million, was reclassified to earnings from discontinued operations on the consolidated statement of earnings in the fourth quarter of 2004. The remaining
charge was recorded as asset impairment and exit costs on the consolidated statement of earnings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2005, the Company sold its fruit snacks assets and incurred a pre-tax asset impairment charge of $93&nbsp;million in recognition of the sale. During
December&nbsp;2005, the Company reached agreements to sell certain assets in Canada and a small biscuit brand in the United States and incurred pre-tax asset impairment charges of
$176&nbsp;million in recognition of these sales. These transactions closed in 2006. These charges, which included the write-off
of all associated intangible assets, were recorded as asset impairment and exit costs on the consolidated statement of earnings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
November&nbsp;2004, following discussions with the Company's joint venture partner in Turkey and an independent valuation of its equity investment, it was determined that a
permanent decline in value had occurred. This valuation resulted in a $47&nbsp;million non-cash pre-tax charge. This charge was recorded as marketing, administration and
research costs on the consolidated statement of earnings. During 2005, the Company's interest in the joint venture was sold. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>67</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=68,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=950341,FOLIO='67',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]EC4185A.;16',USER='ABLIJDE',CD='27-FEB-2007;16:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ec4185_1_68"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
June&nbsp;2005, the Company sold substantially all of its sugar confectionery business for approximately $1.4&nbsp;billion. In 2004, as a result of the anticipated transaction,
the Company recorded non-cash asset impairments totaling $107&nbsp;million. These charges were included in loss from discontinued operations on the consolidated statement of earnings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December&nbsp;2004, the Company announced the sale of its U.S. yogurt assets, which closed in the first quarter of 2005. In 2004, as a result of the anticipated transaction, the
Company recorded asset impairments totaling $8&nbsp;million. This charge was recorded as asset impairment and exit costs on the consolidated statement of earnings. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Total:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The pre-tax asset impairment, exit and implementation costs discussed above, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, were
included in the operating companies income of the following segments: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;4.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Related Party Transactions:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s subsidiary, Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc., provides the Company with various services, including planning, legal, treasury,
auditing, insurance, human resources, office of the secretary, corporate affairs, information technology, aviation and tax services. Billings for these services, which were based on the cost to Altria
Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. to provide such services and a 5% management fee based on wages and benefits, were $178&nbsp;million, $237&nbsp;million and $310&nbsp;million for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. The Company performed at a similar cost various functions in 2006 and 2005 that previously had been provided by Altria Corporate
Services,&nbsp;Inc., resulting in lower service charges in 2006 and 2005. The Company plans to undertake all remaining services currently provided by Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. at a
similar cost in 2007. These costs were paid to Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. monthly. Although the cost of these services cannot be quantified on a stand-alone basis, management has assessed
that the billings are reasonable based on the level of support provided by Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc., and that they reflect all services provided. The cost and nature of the services are
reviewed annually by the Company's Audit Committee, which is comprised of
independent directors. The effects of these transactions are included in operating cash flows in the Company's consolidated statements of cash flows. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2006, the Company purchased certain real estate and personal property located in Wilkes Barre, Pennsylvania, from Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc., for an aggregate purchase
price of $9.3&nbsp;million. In addition, the Company assumed all of Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc.'s rights under a lease for certain real property located in San Antonio, Texas. The Company
also purchased certain personal property located in San Antonio, Texas from Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc., for an aggregate purchase price of $6.0&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Also,
see Note&nbsp;13. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Income Taxes</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> regarding the favorable impact to the Company of the closure of an Internal Revenue Service review
of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s consolidated federal income tax return recorded during 2006. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2005, the Company repatriated certain foreign earnings as part of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s dividend repatriation plan under provisions of the American Jobs Creation Act.
Increased taxes for this repatriation of $21&nbsp;million were reimbursed by Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. The reimbursement was reported in the Company's financial statements as an increase to
additional paid-in capital. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>69</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December&nbsp;2005, the Company purchased an airport hangar and certain personal property located at the hangar in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, from Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc.
for an aggregate purchase price of approximately $3.3&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December&nbsp;2004, the Company purchased two corporate aircraft from Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. for an aggregate purchase price of approximately $47&nbsp;million. The
Company also entered into an Aircraft Management Agreement with Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. in December&nbsp;2004, pursuant to which Altria Corporate Services,&nbsp;Inc. agreed to
perform aircraft management, pilot services, maintenance and other aviation services for the Company. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, the Company had short-term amounts payable to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. of $607&nbsp;million and $652&nbsp;million, respectively.
The amounts payable to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. generally include accrued dividends, taxes and service fees. Interest on intercompany borrowings is based on the applicable London Interbank Offered
Rate. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
fair values of the Company's short-term amounts due to Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. and affiliates approximate carrying amounts. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;5.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Divestitures:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Discontinued Operations:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;2005, the Company sold substantially all of its sugar confectionery business for pre-tax proceeds of approximately $1.4&nbsp;billion.
The sale included the </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Life Savers</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Creme Savers</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Altoids</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Trolli</I></FONT><FONT
SIZE=2> and </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Sugus</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> brands. The Company has
reflected the results of its sugar confectionery business prior to the closing date as discontinued operations on the consolidated statements of earnings. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Summary
results of operations for the sugar confectionery business were as follows: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
loss on sale of discontinued operations, above, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, related largely to taxes on the transaction. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Other:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2006, the Company sold its rice brand and assets, and its industrial coconut assets. The Company also sold its pet snacks brand and assets in 2006 and
recorded tax expense of $57&nbsp;million related to the sale. In addition, the Company incurred a pre-tax asset impairment charge of $86&nbsp;million in 2006 in recognition of this
sale. Additionally, during 2006, the Company sold certain Canadian assets and a small U.S. biscuit brand, and incurred pre-tax asset impairment charges of $176&nbsp;million in 2005 in
recognition of these sales. Also during 2006, the Company sold a U.S. coffee plant. The aggregate proceeds received from these sales were $946&nbsp;million, on which the Company recorded
pre-tax gains of $117&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>70</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=71,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=140359,FOLIO='70',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]EE4185A.;20',USER='ABLIJDE',CD='27-FEB-2007;16:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ee4185_1_71"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2005, the Company sold its fruit snacks assets, and incurred a pre-tax asset impairment charge of $93&nbsp;million in recognition of this sale. Additionally, during
2005, the Company sold its U.K. desserts assets, its U.S. yogurt assets, a small business in Colombia, a minor trademark in Mexico and a small equity investment in Turkey. The aggregate proceeds
received from these sales were $238&nbsp;million, on which the Company recorded pre-tax gains of $108&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2004, the Company sold a Brazilian snack nuts business and trademarks associated with a candy business in Norway. The aggregate proceeds received from the sale of these businesses
were $18&nbsp;million, on which pre-tax losses of $3&nbsp;million were recorded. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
operating results of the other divestitures, discussed above, in the aggregate, were not material to the Company's consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash
flows in any of the periods presented. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;6.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Acquisitions:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>United Biscuits:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September&nbsp;2006, the Company acquired the Spanish and Portuguese operations of United Biscuits ("UB") and rights to all Nabisco trademarks in the
European Union, Eastern Europe, the Middle East and Africa, which UB has held since 2000, for a total cost of approximately $1.1&nbsp;billion. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Spanish and Portuguese operations of UB include its biscuits, dry desserts, canned meats, tomato and fruit juice businesses as well as seven manufacturing facilities and 1,300
employees. From September&nbsp;2006 to December&nbsp;31, 2006, these businesses contributed net revenues of approximately $111&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
non-cash acquisition was financed by the Company's assumption of approximately $541&nbsp;million of debt issued by the acquired business immediately prior to the
acquisition, as well as $530&nbsp;million of value for the redemption of the Company's outstanding investment in UB, primarily deep-discount securities. The redemption of the Company's
investment in UB resulted in a pre-tax gain on closing of approximately $251&nbsp;million ($148&nbsp;million after-tax or $0.09 per diluted share). </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aside
from the debt assumed as part of the acquisition price, the Company acquired assets consisting primarily of goodwill of $734&nbsp;million, other intangible assets of
$217&nbsp;million, property plant and equipment of $161&nbsp;million, receivables of $101&nbsp;million and inventories of $34&nbsp;million. These amounts represent the preliminary allocation
of purchase price and are subject to revision when appraisals are finalized, which is expected to occur during the first half of 2007. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Other:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2004, the Company acquired a U.S.-based beverage business for a total cost of $137&nbsp;million. The effect of this acquisition was not material to the
Company's consolidated financial position, results of operations or cash flows in any of the periods presented. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Inventories:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The cost of approximately 41% and 40% of inventories in 2006 and 2005, respectively, was determined using the LIFO method. The stated LIFO amounts of inventories
were approximately $70&nbsp;million and $71&nbsp;million higher than the current cost of inventories at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>71</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
fair values of the Company's short-term borrowings at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, based upon current market interest rates, approximate the amounts disclosed
above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company maintains revolving credit facilities that have historically been used to support the issuance of commercial paper. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company had a
$4.5&nbsp;billion, multi-year revolving credit facility that expires in April&nbsp;2010 on which no amounts were drawn. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's revolving credit facility, which is for its sole use, requires the maintenance of a minimum net worth of $20.0&nbsp;billion. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company's
net worth was $28.6&nbsp;billion. The Company expects to continue to meet this covenant. The revolving credit facility does not include any other financial tests, any credit rating triggers or any
provisions that could require the posting of collateral. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition to the above, certain international subsidiaries of Kraft maintain credit lines to meet the short-term working capital needs of the international businesses.
These credit lines, which amounted to approximately $1.1&nbsp;billion as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, are for the sole use of the Company's international businesses. Borrowings on these lines
amounted to approximately $200&nbsp;million and $400&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively. At December&nbsp;31, 2006 the Company also had approximately
$0.3&nbsp;billion of outstanding short-term debt related to its United Biscuits acquisition discussed in Note&nbsp;6. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Acquisitions</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company repurchases its Class&nbsp;A common stock in open market transactions. In March&nbsp;2006, the Company completed its $1.5&nbsp;billion two-year
Class&nbsp;A common stock repurchase program, acquiring 49.1&nbsp;million Class&nbsp;A shares at an average price of $30.57 per share. During 2006, repurchases under the $1.5&nbsp;billion
program were 8.5&nbsp;million shares at a cost of $250&nbsp;million, or $29.42 per share. Additionally, in March&nbsp;2006, the Company began a $2.0&nbsp;billion Class&nbsp;A common stock
repurchase program, which is expected to run through 2008. During 2006, the Company repurchased 30.2&nbsp;million shares of its Class&nbsp;A common stock, under its $2.0&nbsp;billion authority,
at a cost of $1.0&nbsp;billion, an average price of $33.06 per share. During 2005, the Company repurchased 39.2&nbsp;million shares of its Class&nbsp;A common stock at a cost of
$1.2&nbsp;billion, an average price of $30.65 per share. During 2004, the Company repurchased 21.5&nbsp;million shares of its Class&nbsp;A common stock at a cost of $700&nbsp;million, an
average price of $32.49 per share. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Class&nbsp;B
common shares issued and outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005 were 1.18&nbsp;billion. Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. held 276.5&nbsp;million Class&nbsp;A
common shares and all of the Class&nbsp;B common shares at December&nbsp;31, 2006. There are no preferred shares issued and outstanding. Class&nbsp;A common shares are </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>73</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=74,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=293434,FOLIO='73',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]EE4185A.;20',USER='ABLIJDE',CD='27-FEB-2007;16:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ee4185_1_74"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>entitled
to one vote each, while Class&nbsp;B common shares are entitled to ten votes each. Therefore, Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. held 98.5% of the combined voting power of the Company's outstanding
capital stock at December&nbsp;31, 2006. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, 161,915,095 shares of common stock were reserved for stock options and other stock awards. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;11.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Stock Plans:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under the Kraft 2005 Performance Incentive Plan (the "2005 Plan"), the Company may grant to eligible employees awards of stock options, stock appreciation rights,
restricted stock, restricted and deferred stock units, and other awards based on the Company's Class&nbsp;A common stock, as well as performance-based annual and long-term incentive
awards. A maximum of 150&nbsp;million shares of the Company's Class&nbsp;A common stock may be issued under the 2005 Plan, of which no more than 45&nbsp;million shares may be awarded as
restricted stock. In addition, in 2006, the Company's Board of Directors adopted and the stockholders approved, the Kraft 2006 Stock Compensation Plan for Non-Employee Directors (the "2006
Directors Plan"). The 2006 Directors Plan replaced the Kraft 2001 Directors Plan. Under the 2006 Directors Plan, the Company may grant up to 500,000 shares of Class&nbsp;A common stock to members of
the Board of Directors who are not full-time employees of the Company or Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc., or their subsidiaries, over a five-year period. Shares available to be
granted under the 2005 Plan and the 2006 Directors Plan at December&nbsp;31, 2006, were 143,669,750 and 481,555, respectively. Restricted shares available for grant under the 2005 Plan at
December&nbsp;31, 2006, were 38,669,750. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Generally,
stock options are granted at an exercise price equal to the market value of the underlying stock on the date of the grant, become exercisable on the first anniversary of the
grant date and have a maximum term of ten years. However, the Company has not granted stock options to its employees since 2002. </FONT></P>

total intrinsic value of options exercised was $6.7&nbsp;million, $0.6&nbsp;million and $3.4&nbsp;million during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004,
respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior
to the initial public offering ("IPO"), certain employees of the Company participated in Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s stock compensation plans. Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. does not
intend to issue additional Altria
Group,&nbsp;Inc. stock compensation to the Company's employees, except for reloads of previously issued options. The reload feature on Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. stock options will cease during 2007. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pre-tax
compensation cost and the related tax benefit for Altria stock option awards for reloads totaled $3&nbsp;million and $1&nbsp;million, respectively, for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. The fair value of </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Restricted Stock Plans:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company may grant shares of restricted stock and rights to receive shares of stock to eligible employees, giving them in most instances all of the rights of
stockholders, except that they may not sell, assign, pledge or otherwise encumber such shares and rights. Such shares and rights are subject to forfeiture if certain employment conditions are not met.
Restricted stock generally vests on the third anniversary of the grant date. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
fair value of the restricted shares and rights at the date of grant is amortized to expense ratably over the restriction period. The Company recorded pre-tax compensation
expense related to restricted stock and rights of $139&nbsp;million (including the pre-tax cumulative effect gain of $9&nbsp;million from the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;123(R)),
$148&nbsp;million and $106&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. The deferred tax benefit recorded related to this compensation expense was
$51&nbsp;million, $54&nbsp;million and $39&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. The unamortized compensation expense related to the Company's
restricted stock and rights was $184&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and is expected to be recognized over a weighted average period of 2&nbsp;years. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's restricted stock and rights activity was as follows for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2006, the United States Internal Revenue Service concluded its examination of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s consolidated tax returns for the years 1996 through 1999 and issued a
final Revenue Agents Report on March&nbsp;15, 2006. Consequently, Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. reimbursed the Company in cash for unrequired federal tax reserves of $337&nbsp;million and
pre-tax interest of $46&nbsp;million ($29&nbsp;million after-tax). </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>76</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=77,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=251842,FOLIO='76',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]EE4185A.;20',USER='ABLIJDE',CD='27-FEB-2007;16:14' -->
<A NAME="page_ee4185_1_77"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>The
Company also recognized net state tax reversals of $39&nbsp;million, resulting in a total net earnings benefit of $405&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
loss from discontinued operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, includes additional tax expense of $280&nbsp;million from the sale of the sugar confectionery
business. The loss from discontinued operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2004, included a deferred income tax benefit of $43&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2006, applicable United States federal income taxes and foreign withholding taxes had not been provided on approximately $3.2&nbsp;billion of accumulated
earnings of foreign subsidiaries that are expected to be permanently reinvested. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
October&nbsp;2004, the American Jobs Creation Act ("the Jobs Act") was signed into law. The Jobs Act includes a deduction for 85% of certain foreign earnings that are repatriated.
In 2005, the Company repatriated approximately $500&nbsp;million of earnings under the provisions of the Jobs Act. Deferred taxes had previously been provided for a portion of the dividends
remitted. The reversal of the deferred taxes more than offset the tax costs to repatriate the earnings and resulted in a net tax reduction of $28&nbsp;million in the consolidated income tax
provision during 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
effective income tax rate on pre-tax earnings differed from the U.S. federal statutory rate for the following reasons for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005
and 2004: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
tax rate in 2006 includes a reimbursement from Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. in cash for unrequired federal tax reserves of $337&nbsp;million, and also includes net state tax reversals
of $39&nbsp;million, due to the conclusion of an audit of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.'s consolidated federal income tax returns for the years 1996 through 1999 in the first quarter of 2006. Included
within the change in tax rates, among other things, are a benefit of $52&nbsp;million in 2006 from the resolution of outstanding items in the Company's international operations, the majority of
which occurred in the first quarter. The tax rate in 2005 includes the settlement of an outstanding U.S. tax claim of $24&nbsp;million in the second quarter; $82&nbsp;million from the resolution
of outstanding items in the Company's international operations, the majority of which was in the first quarter, and $33&nbsp;million of tax impacts associated with the sale of a U.S. biscuit brand.
The 2005 rate also includes a $53&nbsp;million aggregate benefit from the domestic manufacturers' deduction provision and the dividend repatriation provision of the Jobs Act. The tax provision in
2004 includes an $81&nbsp;million favorable resolution of an outstanding tax item, the majority of which occurred in the third quarter of 2004, and the reversal of $35&nbsp;million of tax accruals
that were no longer required due to tax events that occurred during the first quarter of 2004. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
previously discussed in Note&nbsp;2. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, the Company's adoption of FIN 48 will result in an
increase to shareholders' equity as of January&nbsp;1, 2007 of approximately $200&nbsp;million to $225&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>77</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;14.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Segment Reporting:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company manufactures and markets packaged food products, consisting principally of beverages, cheese, snacks, convenient meals and various packaged grocery
products. Kraft manages and reports operating results through two units, Kraft North America Commercial and Kraft International Commercial. Reportable segments for Kraft North America Commercial are
organized and managed principally by product category. Kraft North America Commercial's segments are North America Beverages; North America Cheese&nbsp;&amp; Foodservice; North America Convenient Meals;
North America Grocery; and North America Snacks&nbsp;&amp; Cereals. Kraft International Commercial's operations are organized and managed by geographic location. Kraft International Commercial's
segments are European Union and Developing Markets, Oceania&nbsp;&amp; North Asia. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
October&nbsp;2005, the Company announced that, effective January&nbsp;1, 2006, its Canadian business will be realigned to better integrate it into the Company's North American
business by product category. Beginning in the first quarter of 2006, the operating results of the Canadian business are being reported throughout the North American food segments. In addition, in the
first quarter of 2006, the Company's international businesses were realigned to reflect the reorganization announced within Europe in November&nbsp;2005. The two revised international segments,
which are reflected in these consolidated financial statements and notes, are European Union; and Developing Markets, Oceania&nbsp;&amp; North Asia, the latter to reflect the Company's increased
management focus on developing markets. Accordingly, prior period segment results have been restated. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company's management uses operating companies income, which is defined as operating income before general corporate expenses and amortization of intangibles, to evaluate segment
performance and allocate resources. Management believes it is appropriate to disclose this measure to help investors analyze the business performance and trends of the various business segments.
Interest and other debt expense, net, and provision for income taxes are centrally managed and, accordingly, such items are not presented by segment since they are not included in the measure of
segment profitability reviewed by management. The Company's assets, which are principally in the United States and Europe, are managed geographically. The accounting policies of the segments are the
same as those described in Note&nbsp;2. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>78</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's largest customer, Wal-Mart Stores,&nbsp;Inc. and its affiliates, accounted for approximately 15%, 14% and 14% of consolidated net
revenues for 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. These net revenues occurred primarily in the United States and were across all segments. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>79</FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Items affecting the comparability of the Company's continuing operating results were as follows: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Asset Impairment, Exit and Implementation Costs&#151;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>As discussed in Note&nbsp;3. </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Asset
Impairment, Exit and Implementation Costs</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, the Company recorded charges for these items of $1,097&nbsp;million, $566&nbsp;million and $700&nbsp;million for the years
ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. See Note&nbsp;3 for the breakdown of these pre-tax charges by segment.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Gain on Redemption of UB Investment&#151;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>As more fully discussed in Note&nbsp;6. </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Acquisitions</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, in the
third quarter of 2006, the Company acquired the Spanish and Portuguese operations of UB and rights to all Nabisco trademarks in the
European Union, Eastern Europe, the Middle East and </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>80</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_eg4185_1_81"> </A>
<UL>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Africa.
The redemption of the Company's outstanding investment in UB resulted in a pre-tax gain on closing of approximately $251&nbsp;million. This gain is included in the operating
companies income of the European Union segment. </FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Gains/Losses on Sales of Businesses&#151;</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>During 2006, the Company sold its rice brand and assets, pet snacks brand and
assets, industrial coconut assets, certain Canadian assets, a small U.S. biscuit brand and a U.S. coffee plant for aggregate pre-tax gains of $117&nbsp;million. During 2005, the Company
sold its fruit snacks assets, U.K. desserts assets, U.S. yogurt assets, a small business in Colombia, a minor trademark in Mexico and a small equity investment in Turkey for aggregate
pre-tax gains of $108&nbsp;million. During 2004, the Company sold a Brazilian snack nuts business and trademarks associated with a candy business in Norway for aggregate
pre-tax losses of $3&nbsp;million. These pre-tax (gains) losses were included in the operating companies income of the following segments: </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=83,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=39874,FOLIO='82',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]EG4185A.;29',USER='SLYUBOM',CD=';1-MAR-2007;13:23' -->
<A NAME="page_eg4185_1_83"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Geographic data for net revenues, total assets and long-lived assets (which consist of all non-current assets, other than goodwill, other
intangible assets, net, and prepaid pension assets) were as follows: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=3 ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=8 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>For the Years Ended<BR>
December 31,</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=3 ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=1><B>2006</B></FONT><HR NOSHADE></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Note&nbsp;15.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Benefit Plans:  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In September&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued SFAS No.&nbsp;158, "Employers' Accounting for Defined Benefit Pension and Other Postretirement Plans" ("SFAS
No.&nbsp;158"). SFAS No.&nbsp;158 requires that employers recognize the funded status of their defined benefit pension and other postretirement plans on the consolidated balance sheet and record
as a component of other comprehensive income, net of tax, the gains or losses and prior service costs or credits that have not been recognized as components of net periodic benefit cost. The Company
adopted the recognition and related disclosure provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;158, prospectively, on December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SFAS
No.&nbsp;158 also requires an entity to measure plan assets and benefit obligations as of the date of its fiscal year-end statement of financial position for fiscal
years ending after December&nbsp;15, 2008. The Company's non-U.S. pension plans (other than Canadian pension plans) are measured at September&nbsp;30 of each year. The Company expects
to adopt the measurement date provision of SFAS No.&nbsp;158 and measure these plans as of December&nbsp;31 of each year beginning December&nbsp;31, 2008. The Company is presently evaluating the
impact of the measurement date change, which is not expected to be significant. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>83</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_eg4185_1_84"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
incremental effect of applying SFAS No.&nbsp;158 on individual line items in the consolidated balance sheet at December&nbsp;31, 2006 was as follows: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company sponsors noncontributory defined benefit pension plans covering substantially all U.S. employees. Pension coverage for employees of the Company's
non-U.S. subsidiaries is provided, to the extent deemed appropriate, through separate plans, many of which are governed by local statutory requirements. In addition, the Company's U.S. and
Canadian subsidiaries provide health care and other benefits to substantially all retired employees. Health care benefits for retirees outside the United States and Canada are generally covered
through local government plans. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
plan assets and benefit obligations of the Company's U.S. and Canadian pension plans are measured at December&nbsp;31 of each year and all other non-U.S. pension plans
are measured at September&nbsp;30 of each year. The benefit obligations of the Company's postretirement plans are measured at December&nbsp;31 of each year. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>84</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The accumulated benefit obligation, which represents benefits earned to date, for the U.S. pension plans was $5,584&nbsp;million and $5,580&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively. The </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>85</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=86,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=292351,FOLIO='85',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]EG4185A.;29',USER='SLYUBOM',CD=';1-MAR-2007;13:23' -->
<A NAME="page_eg4185_1_86"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>accumulated
benefit obligation for the non-U.S. pension plans was $3,784&nbsp;million and $3,494&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
U.S. plans with accumulated benefit obligations in excess of plan assets, the projected benefit obligations, accumulated benefit obligations and the fair value of plan assets were
$247&nbsp;million, $196&nbsp;million and $11&nbsp;million, respectively, as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 and $268&nbsp;million, $211&nbsp;million and $14&nbsp;million, respectively, as of
December&nbsp;31, 2005. The majority of these relate to plans for salaried employees that cannot be funded under IRS regulations. For certain non-U.S. plans, which have accumulated
benefit obligations in excess of plan assets, the projected benefit obligation, accumulated benefit obligation and fair value of plan assets were $1,364&nbsp;million, $1,281&nbsp;million and
$646&nbsp;million, respectively, as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, and $2,134&nbsp;million, $1,993&nbsp;million and $1,088&nbsp;million, respectively, as of December&nbsp;31, 2005. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's 2006&nbsp;year-end U.S. and Canadian plans discount rates were developed from a model portfolio of high quality, fixed-income debt
instruments with durations that match the expected future cash flows of the benefit obligations. The 2006&nbsp;year-end discount rates for the Company's non-U.S. plans were
developed from local bond indices that match local benefit obligations as closely as possible. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2006 and 2005, employees left the Company under workforce reduction programs, resulting in settlement losses of $17&nbsp;million and $10&nbsp;million,
respectively, for the U.S. plans. In addition, retiring employees elected lump-sum payments, resulting in settlement losses of $49&nbsp;million, $73&nbsp;million and $41&nbsp;million
in 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. Non-U.S. plant closures and early retirement benefits resulted in curtailment and settlement losses of $13&nbsp;million, $25&nbsp;million and
$7&nbsp;million in 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>86</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
estimated net loss and prior service cost for the combined U.S. and non-U.S. pension plans that is expected to be amortized from accumulated other comprehensive income
into net periodic benefit cost during 2007 are $203&nbsp;million and $15&nbsp;million, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's expected rate of return on plan assets is determined by the plan assets' historical long-term investment performance, current asset
allocation and estimates of future long-term returns by asset class. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Kraft
and certain of its subsidiaries sponsor employee savings plans, to which the Company contributes. These plans cover certain salaried, non-union and union employees. The
Company's contributions and costs are determined by the matching of employee contributions, as defined by the plans. Amounts charged to expense for defined contribution plans totaled
$84&nbsp;million, $94&nbsp;million and $92&nbsp;million in 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Plan Assets  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company's investment strategy is based on an expectation that equity securities will outperform debt securities over the long term. Accordingly, the
composition of the Company's U.S. plan assets is broadly characterized as a 70%/30% allocation between equity and debt securities. The strategy utilizes indexed U.S. equity securities, actively
managed international equity securities and actively managed investment grade debt securities (which constitute 80% or more of debt securities) with lesser allocations to high yield and international
debt securities. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
the plans outside the U.S., the investment strategy is subject to local regulations and the asset/liability profiles of the plans in each individual country. These specific
circumstances result in a level of equity exposure that is typically less than the U.S. plans. In aggregate, the actual asset allocations of the non-U.S. plans are virtually identical to
their respective asset policy targets. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company attempts to mitigate investment risk by rebalancing between equity and debt asset classes as the Company's contributions and monthly benefit payments are made. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company presently makes, and plans to make, contributions, to the extent that they are tax deductible or do not generate an excise tax liability, in order to maintain plan assets in
excess of the accumulated benefit obligation of its funded U.S. and non-U.S. plans. Currently, the Company anticipates making contributions of approximately $16&nbsp;million in 2007 to
its U.S. plans and </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>87</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=10,SEQ=88,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=484665,FOLIO='87',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]EG4185A.;29',USER='SLYUBOM',CD=';1-MAR-2007;13:23' -->
<A NAME="page_eg4185_1_88"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>approximately
$157&nbsp;million in 2007 to its non-U.S. plans, based on current tax law. However, these estimates are subject to change as a result of many factors, including changes in
tax and other benefit laws, as well as asset performance significantly above or below the assumed long-term rate of return on pension assets, or significant changes in interest rates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>Postretirement Benefit Plans:  </I></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net postretirement health care costs consisted of the following for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="LEFT"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The estimated net loss and prior service cost for the postretirement benefit plans that are expected to be amortized from accumulated other comprehensive income
into net postretirement health care costs during 2007 are $67&nbsp;million and $(26) million, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December&nbsp;2003, the United States enacted into law the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003 (the "Act"). The Act establishes a prescription drug
benefit under Medicare, known as "Medicare Part&nbsp;D," and a federal subsidy to sponsors of retiree health care benefit plans that provide a benefit that is at least actuarially equivalent to
Medicare Part&nbsp;D. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
May&nbsp;2004, the FASB issued FASB Staff Position No.&nbsp;106-2, "Accounting and Disclosure Requirements Related to the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and
Modernization Act of 2003" ("FSP 106-2"). FSP 106-2 requires companies to account for the effect of the subsidy on benefits attributable to past service as an actuarial
experience gain and as a reduction of the service cost component of net postretirement health care costs for amounts attributable to current service, if the benefit provided is at least actuarially
equivalent to Medicare Part&nbsp;D. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>88</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=11,SEQ=89,EFW="2176027",CP="KRAFT FOODS INC",DN="1",CHK=867225,FOLIO='88',FILE='DISK124:[07ZAA5.07ZAA4185]EG4185A.;29',USER='SLYUBOM',CD=';1-MAR-2007;13:23' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_ei4185_1_89"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->
